  DECLARATION FOR THE RECORD OF DECISION 
 
SITE NAME AND LOCATION 
 
Cidra Groundwater Contamination Superfund Site  Cidra, Puerto Rico PRN000204538  
STATEMENT OF BASIS AND PURPOSE 
 
This Record of Decision (ROD) documents the se lected remedial action for the Cidra Groundwater 
Contamination Superfund Site, located at the Municipality of Cidra, Pu erto Rico, which was chosen in 
accordance with the requirements of the Comprehe nsive Environmental Response, Compensation, and 
Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA), 42 U.S.C. §§ 9601-9675, as amended, and the National Oil and 
Hazardous Substances Pollution Contingency Plan (NCP), 40 C.F.R. Part 300. This decision document explains the factual and legal basis for selecting the remedy for the Site . This decision is based on the 
Administrative Record file for this Site. Refer to  Appendix I of the Decisi on Summary for copy of the 
Administrative Record Index for this Site.  The Puerto Rico Environmental Quality Board (E QB) concurs with the se lected remedy. Refer to 
Appendix II of the Decision Summary fo r a copy of the c oncurrence letter. 
 
ASSESSMENT OF SITE 
 
The United States Environmental Protection Agency (E PA), in consultation with EQB, has determined 
that actual or threatened releases of hazardous substa nces from the Site, if not addressed by the preferred 
remedy or one of the other active measures consider ed, may present a current or potential threat to 
human health and the environment. Therefore, remedi ation is necessary. This determination is based on 
the conclusions of the Remedial Investigation (RI), Human Health Risk Assessment (HHRA), and the 
Screening Level Ecological Risk Assessment.    The media of concern at the Site are soil and gr oundwater. The source of so il contamination in the 
southern area of the Site is property owned by Rama llo Brothers Printing, Inc ., (Ramallo Property) and 
formerly leased by a company called Cidra Convention Center.  In the northern  area of the Site, the 
source of soil contamination is the Internat ional Dry Cleaner (IDC) facility. The groundwater 
contamination is located in the southern portion of the Site and, based on the resu lts of the RI, originates 
at the Ramallo Property. Based on the results of th e human health and ecological risk assessments 
conducted for the Site, a response action is necessary to protect the public health or welfare of the 
environment.  The selected remedy will be protective of human health  and the environment. Risks to human health due 
to direct contact, ingestion and inhalation would be eliminated si nce contaminated groundwater would 
be treated, contaminated soil would be treated and/ or covered, and the exposure pathways would be 
eliminated. The selected remedy complies with Federal and Commonwealth requirements that are 
legally applicable or relevant and appropriate requirements (ARARs) and is cost effective.  
 
  3 
 DESCRIPTION OF THE SELECTED REMEDY  
 
EPA, in consultation with EQB, selects a reme dy that will address th e soil and groundwater 
contamination detected at the Site . Under the selected remedy, soil co ntamination will be addressed at 
the IDC and the Ramallo Properties by using so il vapor extraction, ex cavation, disposal and 
containment. Groundwater contamination under and downgradient of the Ramallo Property will be 
addressed by implementing an in-situ  treatment remedy to remove vol atile organic compounds (VOCs), 
coupled with long-term monitoring. The principal co mponents of the selected remedy are described 
below:   Alternative IDC-S3 (Soil Vapor Ex traction and Containment), is the selected alternative for the IDC 
property. The remedy includes the following components: 
 
 Soil vapor extraction (SVE) to address the identifi ed VOC hot spot in soil at the IDC Property; 
and 
 Capping in remaining unpaved areas of the IDC Prope rty to prevent water in filtration and direct 
contact with contaminated soil, maintained un til the hotspot is addr essed through SVE. The 
existing concrete slab will also serve to cap co ntaminated soil underlying the building at the IDC 
Property. 
 Alternative R-S3 (Enhanced Soil Vapor Extraction System with Thermal Treatment, Excavation/ 
Disposal/Backfill of Hot Spots, and Capping), is the sel ected alternative for the contaminated soil at the 
Ramallo Property. The remedy includes the following components:  
 
 SVE treatment enhanced with thermal treatme nt to address subsurface hot spot areas; 
 Excavation and off-site disposal of the most c ontaminated surface area hot spots located outside 
of the Ramallo Property building, with tetrachlo roethylene concentratio ns that exceed the 
principal threat criterion of 166 milligrams per kilogram; and 
 Capping in remaining unpaved areas of the Ramallo  Property to prevent water infiltration and 
direct contact with contaminated soil, maintain ed until the hot spot is addressed through SVE. 
The existing concrete slab will also serve to cap contaminated soil underlying the building at the 
Ramallo Property.  
Alternative GW-4 (In-situ Treatmen t and Long-Term Monitoring), is th e selected remedial alternative 
for the groundwater plume located under and downgr adient of the Ramallo Property. The remedy 
includes the following components:   
 In-situ  treatment within a focused area in the sapr olite zone, at the center of the contaminant 
plume, using chemical or biological treatment methods to address the most highly contaminated 
portion of the groundwater;  
 Establishment of a secondary treatment zone , such as a permeable reactive barrier or 
groundwater pump and treatment system, at the downgradient edge of the plume to manage 
plume migration; and 
 Monitored natural attenuation of groundwater contaminants in th e more dilute fringes of the 
contaminant plume. 
 
  4 
 INSTITUTIONAL CONTROLS  
 
While soil and groundwater contaminati on is still present, institutional controls will be implemented to 
help control and limit exposure to hazardous substances at the Site. The types of  institutional controls 
which will be employed for the soil and groundwater at the Site are: 1) existi ng local laws that limit 
installation of drinking water wells without a permit, 2) proprietary co ntrols (e.g., easements/covenants) 
on all or parts of IDC and Ramallo Properties to pr event soil excavation, well in stallation or disturbance 
of the caps or other remedial measures, and 3) info rmational devices such as  advisories published in 
newspapers, periodic letters sent to  local government authorities inform ing them of the need to prevent 
soil excavation and well inst allation, and inspection of  local and/or Commonwealth health department 
records to insure that no wells are installed that could impact the groundwater plume or result in 
exposure to contaminated groundwater.  
EPA
 REGION 2 CLEAN AND GREEN POLICY  
 
The environmental benefits of the preferred reme dy may be enhanced by giving consideration, during 
the design, to technologies and practices that are sustainable in accordance with EPA Region 2 Clean 
and Green Energy Policy. This will include consid eration of green remediation technologies and 
practices. Some examples of practices that would be  applicable are those that reduce emissions of air 
pollutants, minimize fresh water consumption, incor porate native vegetation into  re-vegetation plans, 
and consider beneficial reuse and/or recycling of materials, among others.  
 
DECLARATION OF STATUTORY DETERMINATIONS 
 
STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS  
 
The selected remedy meets the requ irements for remedial actions set forth in CERCLA Section 121, 42 
U.S.C. Section 9621, because it meets the following re quirements: 1) it is protective of human health 
and the environment; 2) it meets a level of standard of control of the hazardous  substances, pollutants, 
and contaminants which at least attains the legally a pplicable or relevant and appropriate requirements 
under the federal and State laws; 3)  it is cost-effective; and 4) it utilizes permanent solutions and 
alternative treatment technologies to  the maximum extent practicable.  
  
STATUTORY PREFERENCE FOR TREATMENT  
 
The selected remedy meets the statut ory preference for the use of remedi es that involve treatment as a 
principal element. 
 
 FIVE-YEAR REVIEW REQUIREMENTS  
 
This remedy will not result in hazardous substances, po llutants, or contaminants remaining at the Cidra 
Groundwater Contamination Superfu nd Site above levels that would allow for unlimited use and 
unrestricted exposure. However, because it may take more than five years to attain the cleanup levels, 
pursuant to Section 121(c) of CERC LA, policy reviews will be conduc ted no less often than once every 
five years after the completion of construction to en sure that the remedy is, or will be, protective of 
human health and environment.  ROD DATA CERTIFICATION CHECKLIST

 SITE NAME, LOCATION, AND DESCRIPTION 
 
The Cidra Groundwater Contamination Superfund Site is  located at the Municipality of Cidra, Puerto 
Rico (Figure 1). The Site has been managed by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as the 
lead agency with the assistance of the Puerto  Rico Environmental Quality Board (EQB) as the 
support agency. The EPA Identification Number assigned to the Site is PRN000204538.  
 
The municipality of Cidra is located in the central-eastern section of Puerto Rico in the northern 
foothills of the Cordillera Central Mountain Range. The site is located just south of the main commercial district of the Cidra Municipality in central eastern Puerto Rico. The Cidra Municipality 
is comprised of 36.5 square miles with a population of 43,480 and a population density of 1,200 
people per square mile. The land use in the vicinity  of the Site includes residential, commercial, 
manufacturing, and agricultural. The topography of the Site encompasses a small plateau where the 
Cidra Commercial District is located, a draina ge area to the south of town where the closed 
municipal wells (discussed below) are located, and a valley below the Cidra Industrial Park. The site 
geology consists of Quaternary silty clays, whic h overlie the fractured Cretaceous-age Pre-Robles 
volcanic bedrock, the major aquifer beneath the Site. The saprolite zone lies between the silty clays and the bedrock. 
 
The Site includes four closed public drinking wa ter supply wells, a groundwater plume contaminated 
with chlorinated volatile organic compounds (VOC s), an industrial facility owned by Ramallo 
Brothers Printing, Inc., (Ramallo), and a former dr y cleaner facility (International Dry Cleaners or 
IDC). (See Figure 2.) The four closed drinking wa ter supply wells are owned by the Puerto Rico 
Aqueduct and Sewer Authority (PRASA). The Ramallo  Property is located in the Cidra Industrial 
Park (CIP), which is currently owned and/or managed by the Puerto Rico Industrial Development 
Company (PRIDCO). The Ramallo Property is presen tly vacant. The IDC Property is located in the 
commercial district of Cidra. The IDC Property includes a two story building on Muñoz Rivera 
Avenue in Cidra. IDC had occupied the first fl oor, which is presently vacant, and an occupied 
residential unit is located on the second floor.  
  
SITE HISTORY AND ENFORCEMENT ACTIVITIES 
 
The Puerto Rico Department of Health (PRDOH) ordered PRASA to close the four public drinking 
water supply wells (two in 1996, one in 1999, and one in 2000) due to the presence of VOC 
contamination in the groundwater. PRDOH detected tetrachloroethene (PCE), 1,1-dichloroethene 
(1,1-DCE) and trichloroethene (TCE) in these wells. The four closed supply wells are: Cidra Well #3 
(“Planta Alcantarillado,” served 117 people); Ci dra Well #4 (“Calle Padilla Final,” served 112 
people); Cidra Well #6 (“Calle Baldorioty,” served 207); and Cidra Well #8 (not in service at the 
time of closure). There are 15 ac tive drinking water supply wells located within four miles of the 
Site, serving a total population of approximately 8,838 people. 
  
According to information obtained by EPA, the Ramallo Property was sold by PRIDCO as a vacant lot to Sierra Instruments PR, Inc., (SI) in 1978. In 1983, SI sold the property to Linear Packaging, 
Inc. Ramallo Escribano, Inc., (REI) purchased the Ramallo Property in September 1986 and 
conducted printing operations there until August 1990. REI manufactured flexographic labels at the 
Ramallo Property. In August 1990, REI sold the facili ty to Ramallo. Ramallo leased the building for 
a number of years to the Cidra Convention Cente r to use as event space. The Ramallo Property 
building has been unoccupied since 2007. 
 
The IDC Property was used for dry cleaning operations until approximately 1994, when the company went out business. Ramallo was notified by EPA of its status as a potentially responsible party (PRP) 
for the Site by letter dated April 25, 2006. Ramallo Brothers filed for bankruptcy in March 2014. No 2 
 other viable PRPs have been identified  to date. EPA’s PRP search is ongoing. 
 
The RI/FS has been funded by EPA. 
 
EPA  POTENTIAL SOURCE AREA INVESTIGATION  
 
In June 2002, EPA collected several groundwater samples from the closed drinking water supply 
wells as part of an Expanded Site Inspection (ESI) to identify potential sources of contamination to 
the Cidra wells. EPA also collected groundwater samples from 20 other active and inactive wells around the Site. The sampling results indicated the pres ence of PCE in the four closed drinking water 
supply wells at concentrations ranging from 0.64 to 12 micrograms per liter (µg/L). In addition, PCE 
was detected in two industrial/potable supply we lls (known as “IVAX” supply wells No.1 and No.2) 
and three industrial wells (GlaxoSmithKline wells No .1 and No.2, and the Millipore-Cidra well). The 
GlaxoSmithKline wells and Millipore ‐Cidra industrial wells are located east of Lago de Cidra and 
are likely not associated with the VOC source that  has impacted the closed public supply wells. 
Related chlorinated solvents, including 1,1 ‐DCE; 1,1 ‐dichloroethane (1,1 ‐DCA); cis ‐1,2‐
dichloroethene (cis ‐1,2‐DCE); carbon tetrachloride; and TCE were also detected in groundwater 
samples. The maximum contaminant level (MCL) for PCE (5 µg/L) was exceeded in the closed drinking water wells, Cidra Well #3 and Cidra Well #8. In addition, 1,1-DCE (7 µg/L) was exceeded 
in IVAX supply wells No.1 and No.2. 
 Chlorinated solvents were not detected at or above the Sample Quantitation Limit of 0.5 µg/L in four 
wells used to determine background conditions (two inactive public wells, Zapera 1 and Zapera 2, 
and two active drinking water wells). Two of the wells, Villa del Carmen and Pelegrin Santos, were 
evaluated as background due to their similar depths and screened intervals to those of the wells 
where observed releases occurred at the Site. The collected groundwater samples were also analyzed 
for semi-volatile organic compounds (SVOCs), pes ticides, polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), and 
inorganic parameters. There were no detections  of SVOCs, pesticides , or PCBs. Inorganic 
parameters were not detected above MCLs in th e groundwater samples, except thallium, which was 
reported at estimated concentrations above its MCL (2 µg/L) in three samples.  
 
In January and February 2003, EPA investigated 12 facilities located in Cidra to determine if they 
could be potential sources of the groundwater contam ination in the area (Figure 3). The investigated 
facilities were: 
 IDC. 
 Shellfoam Products (Shellfoam). 
 SmithKlein Beecham Pharmaceuticals, Inc. 
 TechGroup de Puerto Rico, Inc. (TGP)  
 Zenith Laboratories Caribe , Inc. (which later came to be operated by IVAX 
Pharmaceuticals Caribe, Inc. (IVAX)). 
 Excellent Laundry. 
 Creative Medical Corporation. 
 CMM Laundry. 
 Cidra Metallic Caskets (CMT). 
 Ramallo. 
 CCL Label de Puerto Rico (CCL Label). 
 Caribbean Manufacturi ng Company (CMC). 
 
Direct-push technology was used to complete soil borings at the 12 industrial facilities above, plus 
two background locations, and to collect soil core s (and in one case, a groundwater sample) from 
each borehole at 5-foot intervals. Two to four sets of soil boring samples per facility were collected, 3 
 as well as two borings to represent background. As a result of this sampling effort, five facilities 
remained as possible sources. The facilities that remained possible sources of the contamination and 
corresponding results of the subsurface investigation are described below: 
 
 IDC - The analytical results confirmed that PCE and related substances were present in soil at 
the IDC Property. PCE at 11,000 micrograms per kilogram (µg /kg), TCE at 2,800 µg /kg, 
and cis-1,2-DCE at 5,100 ug/kg were detected in the 4-foot sample. The same compounds 
were detected in the 7-foot sample at lower concentrations, while just cis-1,2-DCE at 6,700 
ug/kg was detected in the 2-foot sample. 
 IVAX - Groundwater samples collected as part of the ESI in June 2002 showed detections of 
1,1-DCE ranging from 7.6 to 12 µg/L and 1,1-DCA ranging from 0.51 to 0.70 µg/L from 
process wells located at the IVAX facility. One surface and two subsurface soil samples were 
collected from two soil borings at this facility, al so as part of the ESI. 1,1-DCE was detected 
at 20 µg /kg (above EPA’s Soil Screening Level (SSL)) in a soil sample collected from this 
facility at a 62-foot depth. However, there were no concentrations detected above background  
in any samples collected from the surficial or intermediate depths. 
 Ramallo Property - One surface and three subsurface soil samples were collected from two 
soil borings as part of the ESI, which showed the presence of PCE at estimated values of 2 
µg/kg and 5 µg/kg in samples collected from each soil boring advanced at this facility. 
 CMC - One surface and two subsurface soil samples were collected from two soil borings at 
the CMC facility as part of the ESI. Data in dicated the presence of cis-1,2-DCE at an 
estimated value of 1 µg/kg. 
 CCL Label - Two surface and three subsurface (including a duplicate) soil samples were 
collected from two soil borings at the CCL facility as part of the ESI. There were no concentrations detected above background in an y of the samples collected from this facility. 
However, based on the facility’s history of us age of chlorinated solvents the facility was 
retained as a possible source. 
 
EPA also collected two sediment samples from drainage channels at CIP. VOCs were not detected in 
any of the drainage channel samples. EPA also collected surface water and sediment samples from five locations in Cidra Lake to evaluate the potential connection between the lake and the 
groundwater contaminated plume. Field-screening a nd analytical results indicated that no VOCs 
were detected from the lake water and sediment samples  
 
EPA
 HAZARD RANKING SYSTEM AND NATIONAL PRIORITY LIST INCLUSION  
 
In December 2003, EPA prepared a Hazard Ranking System (HRS) Report in order to document the 
results of EPA’s investigations and determination to include the Site on the National Priorities List 
(NPL). The HRS Report documented the Site’s lo cation, the known or suspected releases of 
hazardous substances that resulted in the ground water contamination, its proximity to nearby 
drinking water sources, and the populations served by  those drinking water sources. Due to the levels 
of hazardous substances found in the groundwater as well as potential population exposed to the 
groundwater, EPA added the Site to the NPL on July 22, 2004.   
EPA
 REMEDIAL INVESTIGATION /FEASIBILITY STUDY  
 
In July 2007, EPA commenced a fund lead Remedial Investigation (RI) at the Site. The overall 
purpose of the RI was to evaluate the nature and extent of groundwater, soil, soil vapors, surface 
water, and sediment contamination at the Site. Th is was done through a series of comprehensive soil, 
vapor intrusion, surface water, sediment, and groundwater sampling events. Due to the lack of 
existing hydrogeologic data and of a defined source of contamination, the hydrogeologic framework 
of the Site was also defined as part of the RI. Th e RI was designed as a staged field investigation to 4 
 effectively use data collected during the initial stages to focus and refine data collection activities in 
following stages. The RI was conducted in stages. A detailed description of the stage approach used 
in this RI is described in the Sampling Strategy section of this Record of Decision (ROD). Based on 
the soil data, the RI identified the IDC and Ramal lo Properties as sources of contamination at the 
Site. The RI also determined that the groundwater  in the vicinity of the Ramallo Property and 
downgradient of this facility, is contaminated. 
 
An RI Report was published by EPA to document the nature and extent of the contamination at the 
Site. EPA also issued a Baseline Human Health Risk Assessment (HHRA) Report to document the current and future effects of Site contaminants on human health and the environment associated with 
the contamination found at the Site. EPA also conducted a Screening-level Ecological Risk 
Assessment (SLERA) to evaluate any potential for ecological risks from the presence of Site 
contaminants in surface water and sediment. A de tailed description of the HHRA and SLERA for 
this Site is provided in the Summary of Risk Section of this ROD.   
A Feasibility Study (FS) was prepared to present and analyze cleanup alternatives suitable for the 
Site. The purpose of the FS was to identify, deve lop, screen, and evaluate a range of remedial 
alternatives that protect human health and the environment from potential risks at the Site and enable 
EPA to select a remedy for the Site. A detailed de scription of the cleanup alternatives evaluated for 
this Site is provided in the Description of Alternatives Section of this ROD. 
 
HIGHLIGHTS OF COMMUNITY PARTICIPATION 
 
As part of the RI, a community involvement plan (CIP) was developed to assess any community 
concerns about the Site and encourage public partic ipation. As part of the CIP and as required by 
Superfund regulations, EPA prepared a Proposed Plan  for the Site. A Proposed Plan summarizes the 
remedial alternatives and identifies EPA’s preferred alternative and the rationale for the preferred 
remedy. On November 20, 2014, EPA made available to the public the Proposed Plan, the RI Report, 
the HHRA and SLERA Reports, and the FS Report fo r the Site. All of these documents along with 
others are included in the Administrative Record for the Site, which was made available to the public 
at the following locations: EPA’s Docket Room in New York, New York; Cidra’s Electronic Public 
Library; EQB’s Superfund File Room in Sa n Juan, Puerto Rico; and EPA’s Caribbean 
Environmental Protection Division Office in San Juan, Puerto Rico. A copy of the Administrative 
Record Index for the Site is provided in Appendix I of this ROD.  
 
A notice of the availability of the Proposed Plan, and supporting documentation was published in the 
“El Vocero” newspaper on November 20, 2013. A public comment period was held from November 20, 2013 to December 20, 2013. In addition, a public meeting was held on December 4, 2013 at 
Cidra City Hall from 6:00 pm to 8:00 pm. The purpose of the public meeting was to present the 
Proposed Plan to the community and provide an oppor tunity for the public to ask questions or give 
comments on the proposed remedial alternatives desc ribed in the Proposed Plan and EPA’s preferred 
alternative. At this meeting, representatives from EPA and EQB answered questions and received comments about the remedial activities conducted at the Site and the proposed cleanup plan for the 
Site. No substantive comments were received during the public meeting. A copy of the attendance 
sheet for this meeting can be found in Appendix VI of this ROD. Appendix VII of this ROD contains 
the official transcript of the public meeting. In addition, EPA’s response to written comments 
received during the public comment period is included in the Responsiveness Summary, which is part of this ROD.  
  
SCOPE AND ROLE OF RESPONSE ACTION 
 
The principal problem at the Site is the presence of soil and groundwater contamination at levels that 5 
 represent an unacceptable risk to human health and the environment. EPA is addressing the cleanup 
of the Site by implementing a single, comprehensive remedial action to address the soil and 
groundwater contamination at the Site. One component of the response action will address soil 
contamination at the two locations (IDC and Ra mallo Properties) where high concentrations of 
VOCs in soil act as potential sources of contamin ation to groundwater, while another component will 
address the groundwater contamination at and downgradient of the Ramallo Property. In addition, 
EPA is addressing the potential indoor risk pathway that exists as a result of contaminated vapors 
moving from contaminated soil into buildings (vapor intrusion) at or near the IDC and the Ramallo 
properties.  
SITE CHARACTERISTICS 
 
C
ONCEPTUAL SITE MODEL  
 
A Conceptual Site Model (CSM) was developed to integrate the different types of information 
related to the Site collected during the RI, includ ing geology, hydrogeology, background, setting, and 
the fate and transport of cont aminants. Figure 4 and Figure 5 in  the Appendix III of this ROD 
illustrate the CSM for the Site. The two main sources of soil contamination were identified at the 
IDC and Ramallo Properties. Both facilities are lo cated upgradient of the contaminated groundwater 
plume. At the IDC Property, PCE levels in soil were as high as 1,700,000 µg/kg in the top 12 feet of 
soil located in an alley in the southeastern corner  of the IDC Property. Samples taken as deep as 60 
feet below ground surface (bgs) in other areas of  the IDC Property still exceeded the screening 
criterion. At the Ramallo Property, the highest leve l of PCE detection, 3,300,000 µg/kg, was found in 
the top two feet of soil along the eastern side of  the Property boundary. Exceedances of the screening 
criteria were found at the Ramallo Property as deep as 72 feet bgs.  
 
The most likely scenario for contaminant transport for the Site is described as follows: 
 
 IDC Property 
 
Contaminants were likely discharged directly to the ground at the IDC Property. The majority of the 
surface in the vicinity of the IDC Property is overlain by buildings and roads, which prohibits the 
majority of precipitation from infiltrating into the laye r of clayey overburden. As a result, the bulk of 
precipitation drains via overland flow toward a northern drainage area.   
The remainder migrates downward through fractures in the soil in unpaved areas. Infiltration of 
contamination into the IDC Property soil is possibly enhanced by lineations in the clay overburden. Along the infiltration pathways, contamination diffuses into the surrounding low permeability clay 
matrix. Contaminant transport to the depth of groundw ater through this unit may be hindered in this 
area due to greater overburden thickness in this ar ea (approximately 30 feet thicker) and gradation to 
finer-grained soils with depth. Low-levels of contamination eventually reach the saprolite 
groundwater zone (discussed below) and migrate to the top of bedrock and enter the bedrock bedding 
planes and fractures. The overall flow direction is to the southwest.  
 
 Ramallo Property  
 
Similar to the IDC Property, contaminants were likely discharged directly to the ground at the 
Ramallo Property and migrated downward with precipitation through lineations in the overburden, 
drawing dissolved contamination deeper into the soils. Along these flow paths, contamination 
diffuses into the surrounding low permeability clay matrix. Contamination then migrated into the 
groundwater aquifer in the underlying saprolite zone . As described in the RI, the PCE contamination 
moves with groundwater flow in the saprolite toward the Arroyata River to the West. The saprolite 6 
 layer contains the highest levels of PCE in ground water at the Site, and recharges the underlying 
bedrock aquifer.  
 
 Surface Water and Sediment 
 
Groundwater contamination migrating to the saprolit e zone from the Ramallo Property discharges to 
the Arroyata River, approximately 1,700 feet downgradient, via seeps. Contaminant levels in the 
surface water, which are below screening criteria, are highest in areas adjacent to nearby saprolite 
wells which had concentrations exceeding MCLs and generally decrease downstream. Contaminant 
levels in the sediments were either not detected or below screening criteria. 
 
CONTAMINATION OVERVIEW  
 
The RI identified three sources of contamination for the Site. These three sources are:  
 An area of VOC-contaminated soil approximately 100 square feet (ft2) in size at the IDC 
Property; 
 An area of VOC-contaminated soil approximately 1,000 ft2 in size at the Ramallo Property; 
and 
 An area of VOC-contaminated groundwater approximately 400,000 ft2 underneath and 
downgradient of the Ramallo Property.  
 
Topography and Drainage 
 
Cidra is located in the central-eastern section of Puerto Rico in the northern foothills of the 
Cordillera Central Mountain Range. The Cidra comme rcial district is approximately 1,400 feet above 
mean sea level. The topography generally slopes south from the commercial district to a narrow 
southwest-trending valley and an unnamed stream (referred to as the northern drainage area).  
 The topography of the CIP, where the Ramallo Property is located, generally slopes southwest 
toward the Arroyata River. The unnamed stream drains the area surrounding the municipal cemetery, 
and flows into the Arroyata River southwest of the Site (Figure 2).  
 
Most of the surface water drainage from the Site flows south and west toward the unnamed stream 
and the Arroyata River a tributary of the La Plata Ri ver. Areas to the north and east of the Site drain 
into the Cidra Lake located 0.5 miles east of the Site, which is part of the Bayamon River drainage 
basin. Cidra Lake is a man-made reservoir and is a popular fishing destination. A surface water 
intake for drinking water is located approximately 2.2 miles downstream of the Cidra Lake. There 
are no wetlands located within the Site. Although th e Site is not located within the Arroyata River 
floodplain, three down-gradient monitoring wells instal led as part of the RI are located within the 
floodplain. 
 
Geology 
 The geology in and around the Site is illustrated on the U.S. Geological Survey Comerio Quadrangle 
geologic outcrop map (Figure 6). The three strata un its encountered at the Site are the Quaternary-
age terrace deposits composed of silt and clay, a saprolite zone  (decomposed bedrock), and the 
underlying Cretaceous-age Pre-Robles volcanic rocks. The units are described below.  
 
 Quaternary Upper Silty Clay – This unconso lidated overburden unit consists of reddish-
brown silty clay grading to gray and brown si lty clay. The depth to the bottom of the silty 
clay unit varies from 55 feet bgs to 105 feet bgs. Generally, the silty clay layer is thicker in 
the area near the IDC Property than in the area near Ramallo Property.  7 
  
 Saprolite Zone – The saprolite unit is the result of chemical weathering of the underlying 
volcanic rocks. The material is a hard, wet, brown to light brown, sandy to silty clay with 
abundant dark brown to brown, angular to very angular, mafic rock fragments with fine-
grained texture. The saprolite crumbles easily under light pressure. Where present, the unit 
ranges in thickness from 45 feet to 60 feet. The contact between the saprolite and underlying bedrock ranged from 109 to 156 feet bgs.  
 
 Pre-Robles Volcanic Rock (Formation J) - The core of the region is comprised of Cretaceous 
to Early Tertiary volcanic rocks of the Pre-Robles Formation (Formation J), which are the 
oldest rocks exposed in the Comerio geologic quadrangle. The rocks are estimated to be a 
maximum of approximately 8,900 feet thick and consist mostly of massive volcanic breccia. 
Massive to poorly stratified tuffs are interlayered with the volcanic breccia. Locally, volcanic 
conglomerates outcrop periodically. 
 
The drinking water supply wells and the multiport mon itoring wells (installed as part of the RI) were 
installed in Pre-Robles Volcanic Rock (Formation J) uni t, and well logs describe it as blue, brown, or 
black volcanic rock. A rock core collected from 123 feet bgs to 328 ft bgs revealed that the 
volcanoclastic rocks consist of well-defined dark bluish-gray to dark gray to dark reddish-brown 
clasts in a green fine-grained matrix with inclusi ons of light greenish gray and white crystals. Some 
1/8 inch to 1/4inch thick veins (possibly quartz) a nd 45 degree angle fractures (198 ft to 199 feet bgs) 
were observed in the core. Evidence of metamorphism was observed at 202 feet bgs.  
 
Key structural features in the vicinity of the Site include the Arroyata Fault, located 0.25 miles to the 
south of the Cidra commercial district and adjacent to the CIP. The fault is weathered and has been 
hydrothermally altered across much of the area to  the south of Cidra. Displacement along it is 
uncertain, but is generally strike-slip with a minor ob lique component (reverses to the east of Cidra.)  
 Hydrogeology 
 The Site encompasses a small plateau where the commercial district is located, a drainage area to the south of Cidra where the closed drinking water public supply wells are located, and a valley below 
the CIP. The main aquifer of concern that lies bene ath the Site is the Pre-Robles volcanic bedrock. 
The closed and active public supply wells are comple ted in this aquifer at total depths ranging from 
110 feet bgs to 705 feet bgs. The Site is immediately underlain by the Quaternary silty clays, which 
overlie the fractured Cretaceous-age Pre-Robles vo lcanic bedrock. The saprolite zone lies between 
the silty clays and the bedrock. The hydrogeology of these units is described below.  
 
 Hydrogeology of the Upper Silty Clay (V adose Zone) - Silts and clays have low 
permeabilities, which tend to hinder groundwater flow through the overburden to the water 
table. However, the fractures and lineations observed in the silty clays may provide secondary permeability that enhances groundwat er flow to the underlying units. Near the 
Ramallo and IDC Properties, the water table is ty pically found at a depth of approximately 70 
feet bgs in this unit. 
 
 Hydrogeology of the Saprolite Unit - The saprolite unit or zone below the silty clay was 
observed during the well installation activities to  be a major water-bearing unit. It stores and 
provides water recharge to the underlying bedrock aquifer. This unit is semi-confined by the 
overlying silty clay soils, as evidenced by rising water level conditions in drilling rods upon 
reaching this zone. During well installation activities, very little water was encountered while 
drilling through the silty clay unit. Once the saprolite unit and groundwater were encountered, water levels rose approximately  20 feet to 54 feet. Once in this unit, 8 
 groundwater flows downward and laterally to the west/southwest and enters fractures at the 
top of the volcanic bedrock.  
 
 Hydrogeology of the Pre-Robles Volcanic Ro ck - Groundwater flow in the bedrock is 
complicated by fractures and bedding planes and by the Site location relative to the two 
major river basins. The porosity of the bedrock is only two to three percent, but joints and fractures can enhance groundwater flow consider ably. Bedding planes in the bedrock act as 
individual aquifers, separated by aquitards consis ting of relatively low permeability bedrock, 
where less fracturing is present. Across the ma jority of the Site, groundwater encounters 
bedding planes in the bedrock aquifer and flows laterally along the strike to the north and 
south and then down dips to the west. The resulting overall groundwater flow is to the 
west/southwest, toward Arroyata River, located south and west of the Site.  
 Cultural Resources 
 
A Cultural Resources Survey (CRS) was performed  during the RI for the Site to assess the 
archaeological sensitivity in the area of potential  effects (APE). The APE consisted of approximately 
144 acres of Cidra. The CRS Report can be found in the RI Report prepared for the Site. The CRS 
concluded that portions of the APE possessed high  and moderate sensitivity for archaeological 
resources. Historic evidence indicates that at l east by the 1880s, the Cidra Municipal Cemetery was 
established in the APE. Grave markers at the wester n end of the cemetery appear to exhibit evidence 
of having been relocated during past expansions of the cemetery. The precise boundaries of 
nineteenth century cemeteries are often not accurately depicted in historic records, and associated 
historic burials are often identified outside recorded  cemetery limits. Areas near the cemetery possess 
a high sensitivity for historic burials.  
 
Elsewhere, in the western and southern portion of the APE, on the basis of cartographic evidence, 
field reconnaissance, and the review of geoprobe  soil boring logs, zones of high and moderate 
sensitivity for archaeological resources have be en delineated. Other portions of the APE possess 
extensive evidence of disturbance associated with  previous earthmoving activities and have a low 
sensitivity with respect to the survival of intact archaeological resources. However, parking lots and 
yard areas within the northern portion of the low sensitivity zone and along Route 171 near the Site 
may have the potential for deep historic features. These may include wells or privies associated with 
nineteenth century structures as depicted on historical maps of these areas.   
Sampling Strategy 
 
EPA completed the majority of the field work for the RI for the Site in June 2013. The purpose of the 
RI, which was to determine the nature and extent of contamination at the Site, was accomplished by 
collecting and analyzing samples from various media and then comparing analytical results to 
federal, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico (Com monwealth), and Site-specific screening criteria. 
Five chemicals were identified as Site-related cont aminants: PCE, TCE, cis-1,2-DCE, 1,1-DCE, and 
vinyl chloride. These five VOCs were detected the most frequently and at the highest levels in source 
area soil samples and other affected media including groundwater, surface water, and sediment. 
TCE, cis‐1,2‐DCE, 1,1‐DCE, and vinyl chloride are all daughter (breakdown) products of the 
reductive dechlorination process of PCE. TCE degrades to either 1,2 ‐DCE (with the cis ‐isomer more 
prevalent than the trans-isomer) or 1,1-DCE.  The RI also investigated the Site for the presence of Site contaminants in the form of nonaqueous 
phase liquids (NAPLs). Site contaminants are chlo rinated VOCs, which are denser than water. While 
those contaminants are also referred to as de nse nonaqueous phase liqu ids (DNAPLs), no DNAPLs 
were directly observed in soil or groundwater at the Site. However, at both the IDC and Ramallo 9 
 Properties, elevated concentrations of Site-rela ted VOCs were detected in the vadose zone at 
concentrations that exceeded the soil saturation limit for PCE of 166 milligrams per kilogram 
(mg/kg), indicating the potential pres ence of DNAPLs at both facilities. 
 The overall objective of the soil investigation was to characterize the surface and sub-surface soils at 
potential source facilities in the vicinity of the Site. The investigated facilities included the locations 
of four former dry cleaners (the former IDC Pr operty, and three which are now a coffee shop, a 
business known as Don Quixote Pizza, and a business known as Ramoncito) located in the Cidra 
commercial district, Esso Gas Station and seven industrial facilities located in the CIP. The soil investigation was conducted in two stages. During Stage 1, ten soil borings were advanced at the 
locations of the four former dry cleaners (Refer to Figure 7 of this ROD for the soil boring 
locations). Soil samples were sent to Contract La boratory Program (CLP) laboratories for analysis of 
full Target Compound List (TCL) and Target Analyt e List (TAL) parameters, with select samples 
also sent to EPA Region 2’s Division of Environm ental Science and Assessment (DESA) laboratory 
for analysis of pH, total organic carbon (TOC), and grain size distribution. Based on the results from 
this stage of the RI, of the four dry cleaner locations, only the IDC Property was further evaluated 
during the second investigation stage (Stage 2). As pa rt of the Stage 2 investigation, ten additional 
soil borings were advanced at the IDC Property (Figure 7). 
 
Based on the results of the Stage 1 soil boring sample s of the other suspected source areas at the Site, 
the Ramallo Property, CCL Label, and ESSO facilitie s were further evaluated as part of the Stage 2 
investigation. Two additional industrial facilities (ENCO and DJ Manufacturing) located at the CIP 
were also identified for soil boring samples investigation due to their proximity to the other 
investigated facilities. Stage 2 soil boring locations at these industrial facilities, with the exception of 
the ESSO Gas Station, are shown on Figure 8; soil borings at the ESSO Gas Station are shown on 
Figure 9. 
 
A staged groundwater investigation was also conducted at the Site as part of the RI. The Stage 1 
investigation consisted of the installation of six mu ltiport wells (MPWs) advanced in the vicinity of 
the four closed drinking water supply wells. Pack er sampling was performed in the six boreholes to 
provide discrete ‐depth, screening ‐level groundwater data to support selection of multiport 
monitoring well monitoring intervals. Six “FLUTe” system multiport monitoring wells were 
installed in the bedrock boreholes in December 20 08. The multiport well systems contained four to 
seven ports, based on results from the packer sampling and downhole geophysical logs. Multiport 
monitoring well locations are shown on Figure 10.   
As part of the Stage 2 groundwater investigation, a total of eleven monitoring wells were installed in 
the saprolite zone (Figure 10. Groundwater samp les were collected from the saprolite monitoring 
wells, multiport monitoring wells installed during Stage 1, and the four closed drinking water supply 
wells. 
 
As part of the Stage 2 groundwater  investigation, EPA collected ten surface water and sediment 
samples to determine if contaminants had migrated through the groundwater to surface water and sediments in Arroyata River, located downgradient of  the Site. Samples were strategically located in 
areas where groundwater was expected to discharge in to the river. Samples were collected during the 
rainy season and, therefore, it is likely that the river was being recharged by the groundwater. Figure 
11 shows the surface water and sediment sampling locations. Stream gauges were also installed and 
water level measurements were recorded during the Stage 2. One surface water sample and one 
sediment sample were collected upstream of the Si te to represent background conditions. Sampling 
began at the most downstream location and pr oceeded upstream. The two most downgradient 
samples were collected at, and downgradient of, the confluence with the unnamed stream that drains the area surrounding the municipal cemetery. Surface water samples were collected mid-stream 10 
 directly into sample containers submerged below the stream surface. Surface water samples were 
analyzed for TCL VOCs and TAL inorganics through the CLP. Samples were also analyzed for 
methane, ethane, ethene, nitrate, nitrite, sulfate, sulfide, alkalinity, ammonia, chloride, TOC, Total

In May 2014, EPA resampled groundwater, surface water, and sediment for PCE and other analytes to compare it to the data collected for these media in 2012. After comparing the results, EPA 
determined that: 1) the two data sets for PCE co ntamination in the groundwater were comparable; 2) 
the two data sets for PCE contamination in the surface water were statistically different; and, 3) no 
Site-related contaminants were detected in the sediments in the 2014 sampling events above the 
screening criterion. The differences in the 2012 and 2014 surface water results do not change the 
outcome of the risk analysis as described in the Final HHRA and Final FS because the risk to 
recreational users from surface waters is not derived from PCE. See, “Comparison of 2012 and 2014 
Data for the Cidra Groundwater Contamination Site,” issued on July 1, 2014.  
Since volatilization is an important transport proces s for chlorinated VOCs in soil, a vapor intrusion 
(VI) investigation was conducted at the IDC Property,  Ramallo Property, and structures adjacent to

Property. One ambient air sample was collected upwind of the IDC Property. Indoor air and sub ‐slab 
soil vapor samples were also collected at and adjacent to the Ramallo Property. Samples were also collected at CCL Label, ENCO, and the Praxedes Public Housing facilities.

 Sources of Contamination 
 
The main source of contamination to one of the supply wells in the southern area of the Site is the 
Ramallo Property, specifically in the southeastern side  of this facility, where PCE levels in soil were 
as high as 3,300,000 µg/kg. PCE was detected in al l 23 soil borings, and exceeded screening criteria 
in nine borings. The soil screening criteria used  for Site-related contaminants were based on the 13 
 lower of the value necessary for protection of human health and for protection of groundwater 
(dilution attenuation factor of 20) from EPA’s Re gional Screening Levels for Contaminants at 
Superfund Sites. The highest levels of Site-related contaminants were found in shallow soils in the 
southeastern portion of the Ramallo Property. The analytical results found the following levels of VOCs in soil: PCE at 3,300,000 µg/kg, TCE at 2,700 µg/kg, cis-1,2-DCE at 41,000 µg/kg, 1,1-DCE 
at 120 µg/kg, and vinyl chloride at 2,000 µg/kg.  Site-related contaminants were detected above 
screening criteria at the CCL Label, and ENCO facilities and below screening criteria at DJ 
Manufacturing facility. These detections are likely due  to the proximity of these facilities to the 
identified source (Ramallo Property). At CCL Label, the highest levels of PCE, the only Site-related 
VOC that exceeded screening criteria, were detected in deep soils in the southeastern corner of the 
property, on the border with the Ramallo Property. At ENCO, the highest levels were found in two 
borings along the western edge of the Ramallo Property, on the border with the Ramallo Property. 
PCE was the only Site-related VOC detected at DJ  Manufacturing but was be low screening criteria. 
As such, these three facilities are not cons idered sources of groundwater contamination.  
 
The highest levels of Site-related contaminants in soil in the northern drainage area were found at the 
IDC Property, the main source of contamination in the northern area of the Site. PCE levels in soil in the southeastern portion of the facility were as high as 1,700,000 µg/kg, TCE was as high as 39,000 
µg/kg, cis-1,2-DCE was as high as 29,000 J µg/kg, and vinyl chloride was as high as 1,200 µg/kg. 
These levels were all found from 4-8 ft bgs in samp les located in the southwestern corner of the IDC 
Property. Several samples at the bottom of bo rings (i.e., from 48-60 feet bgs) also exhibited 
exceedances of screening criteria, indicating that soil contamination may extend to deeper depths. 
However, contaminant levels generally decrease with depth because the soils become much tighter 
with depth. None of the other former dry cleaner facilities (Ramoncito, Don Quixote Pizza, and the 
Coffee Shop in the northern area) had Site-related co ntaminants at levels above screening criteria. 
The ESSO gas station also did not have any Site-related contaminants above screening criteria. 
 
Types of Contaminants and Migration 
 The primary Site-related contaminants identified at  the Site include five chlorinated VOCs: TCE; 
PCE; cis-1,2-DCE; 1,1-DCE; and vinyl chloride. These five VOCs were detected the most frequently 
and at the highest levels in source area soil samples and affected media including groundwater, surface water, and sediment. Based on the high levels of PCE at the IDC and Ramallo Properties, 
PCE is assumed to have been released to the gr ound as a raw or waste product. Potential migration 
mechanisms for Site contaminants in the soil incl ude leaching to groundwater , volatilization, direct 
discharge and surface runoff, and degradation. 
 The soil data indicated that significant masses of  PCE and its degradation products are retained by 
capillary forces in the pores of soil, primarily in the shallow intervals in the Ramallo and IDC 
Properties. Additionally, these contaminants have mi grated downward to deeper subsurface soils to 
depths of at least 56 feet to 60 feet at the IDC Property and 68 feet to 72 feet at the Ramallo 
Property. The chlorinated VOCs have leached from the soil and moved down into groundwater at the Ramallo Property. Does this mean that the Ramallo property is the sole source for the groundwater 
plume? 
 
In the area surrounding the IDC Property, the majority of the land surface is low permeability asphalt 
and concrete and impermeable building slabs, whic h minimizes percolation of rainwater through soil. 
As a result, the bulk of precipitation drains via over land flow toward the northern drainage area. This 
limits dissolution of chlorinated VOCs in rainwa ter and their subsequent transport to groundwater. 
Precipitation that does not run off, and instead migrates downward through the overburden in unpaved areas, becomes contaminated as it flows th rough the source area soils. Vertical contaminant 
transport may be hindered in this area due to greate r overburden thickness and tighter soils at depth. 14 
 PCE and other chlorinated VOCs in the source areas, especially possible free phase PCE, will 
constitute a source for continuous dissolution of  contaminants to the water phase, resulting in 
contamination that could persist for decades. 
 Chlorinated VOCs can reach the groundwater zone eith er dissolved in water or as pure liquid phase. 
The dissolved PCE plume currently extends an estimated 1,600 feet downgradient from the Ramallo 
Property. The fate of a chemical in the environment is a function of its physical and chemical 
properties and conditions at the Site. The potential for environmental transport is a function of the 
conditions at the Site, in cluding geological and hydrogeological ch aracteristics. The primary fate and 
transport aspects at the Site  are summarized below.  
 
 PCE and its degradation products have migrated from the ground surface through the 
unconsolidated zone and into groundwater at the Ramallo Property. Some of the PCE mass is retained by capillary forces in the pores of soil.  
 The greatest potential for the transport of the chlorinated VOCs is through continuous 
dissolution of contaminants in soil and ve rtical migration to groundwater, groundwater 
migration, and volatilization. 
 Dissolved contaminants underneath and downgradient of the Ramallo Property move with 
the groundwater flow in the saprolite toward the southwest and eventually discharge into 
the Arroyata River. Dissolved contaminants in the saprolite may enter the shallow 
bedrock groundwater through bedroc k bedding planes and fractures.  
 Chlorinated VOCs in soil and groundwater are migrating as vapor at both the Ramallo 
and IDC Properties. Vapor intrusion is a potential concern for current or future occupied 
buildings at the Ramallo and IDC Properties.  
 
The four closed drinking water supply wells operated by PRASA and the multiport monitoring wells 
(installed as part of the RI) were installed at the Pre-Robles Volcanic Rock (Formation J) unit. The 
well logs described the Pre-Robles Volcanic Ro ck (Formation J) unit as blue, brown, or black 
volcanic rock. A rock core collected from 123 to 328 feet bgs revealed the volcanoclastic rocks 
consist of well-defined dark bluish-gray to dark gray to dark reddish-brown clasts in a green fine-
grained matrix with inclusions of light greenish gray and white crystals. Some 1/8 inch to 1/4 inch 
thick veins (possibly quartz) and 45 degree angle fr actures (198 to 199 feet bgs) were observed in the 
core. Evidence of metamorphism was observed at 202 feet bgs.   
The affected aquifer consists of saprolite (weat hered bedrock) unit overlying the fractured Pre 
Robles Volcanic Rock (Formation J) unit. The depth to the saprolite unit in the affected plume area 
varies between 30 to 75 feet bgs and is under semi-confined conditions due to the overlying silty clay 
overburden. Groundwater flow is to west/southwe st and recharges the underlying volcanic bedrock 
and discharges to the Arroyata River to the southwest. The depth to bedrock in the affected area 
varies between 110 and 120 feet bgs. The groundwate r is under confined conditions and flows along 
bedding planes and fractures to the west/southwest toward the Arroyata River. 
 Assessment of Natural Attenuation at the Site 
 
Natural attenuation refers to the naturally occurr ing processes in soil and groundwater including 
biodegradation by subsurface microorganisms, r eactions with naturally occurring minerals, and 
sorption on geologic media. These processes can achieve a reduction in the total mass, toxicity, 
mobility, volume or concentration of contaminants. If testing indicates that conditions are favorable 
for natural attenuation at a site, the Agency can  consider relying on monitored natural attenuation 
(MNA) as a remedy, or as a component to a remedy. 
 
 
During the RI investigation, MNA indicator paramete rs were collected and analyzed in the field and 15 
 by an off‐site laboratory in order to evaluate whether subsurface conditions are conducive to in‐situ 
natural degradation of chlorinated VOCs. The dissol ved oxygen (DO) concentrations near the source 
area were below 0.5 milligrams per liter, which is supportive of reductive dechlorination. The pH 
and temperature of groundwater samples were also  within optimal ranges for active biological 
activity. Degradation products of PCE and TCE are present in the source ar ea and in downgradient 
monitoring wells in both the saprolite and bedrock groundwater. The plume is also narrow 
(approximately 300 feet at the maximum width) and limited to a zone that is approximately 20 to 35 feet thick in the saprolite unit.  Groundwater sampling documents a sharp drop in concentrations 
from 1,700 µg/L PCE in the saprolite to 12 µg/L PCE in the top of the competent bedrock, which is 
indicative that attenuation is occurring, and that the plume itself is not expanding. Furthermore, the 
concentrations in the upper rock are stable, indicating no expansion of the plume to this area.  
 
CURRENT AND POTENTIAL FUTURE SITE AND RESOURCE USES 
 
The Site area includes land types as follows: forest  (34 percent), agriculture/rural (49 percent), and 
urban (16 percent). The land uses for the Site  area are primarily residential, commercial, 
manufacturing, and agricultural. The identified s ources of contamination have mixed uses. The IDC 
Property is zoned for commercial and residential use and the Ramallo Property is zoned for an 
industrial use. These land uses are not anticipated to change in the future. 
 
SUMMARY OF SITE RISKS  
 
As part of the RI/FS, EPA conducted a baseline ri sk assessment to estimate the current and future 
effects of contaminants on human health and the environment. A baseline risk assessment is an 
analysis of the potential adverse human health and ecological effects of releases of hazardous 
substances from a site in the absence of any acti ons or controls to mitigate such releases, under 
current and future land uses. It provides the basi s for taking action and identifies the contaminants 
and exposure pathways that need to be addressed by the remedial action. The baseline risk 
assessment includes a human health risk assessment and an ecological risk assessment. The risks and 
hazards for the Site which were presented in the baseline risk assessment are summarized in this section. 
 
H
UMAN HEALTH RISK ASSESSMENT (HHRA) 
 
A four-step process is utilized for assessing Si te related human health risks for a reasonable 
maximum exposure scenario: Hazard Identification – uses the analytical data collected to identify the 
contaminants of potential concern (COPCs) at the Site for each medium, with consideration of a 
number of factors explained below; Exposure Assess ment - estimates the magnitude of actual and/or 
potential human exposures, the frequency and duration of these exposures, and the pathways (e.g., 
ingesting contaminated well-water) by which humans  are potentially exposed; Toxicity Assessment - 
determines the types of adverse health effects associated with chemical exposures, and the 
relationship between magnitude of exposure (dose) and severity of adverse effects (response); and 
Risk Characterization - summarizes and combines outputs of the exposure and toxicity assessments 
to provide a quantitative assessment of Site relate d risks. The risk characterization also identifies 
contamination with concentrations which exceed accep table levels, defined by the NCP as an excess 
lifetime cancer risk greater than 1 × 10-6 – 1 × 10-4, an excess of lifetime cancer risk greater than 1 × 
10-6 (i.e., point of departure) combined with Site specific circumstances, or a Hazard Index (HI) 
greater than 1.0; contaminants at these concentra tions are considered COCs and are typically those 
that will require remediation at the Site.  
 
 16

In this step, the COPCs in each medium were identified based on such factors as toxicity, frequency 
of occurrence, fate and transport of the contaminan ts in the environment, concentrations, mobility, 
persistence, and bioaccumulation. COPCs were selected by comparing the maximum detected 
concentration of each analyte in Site media with available risk-based screening values. Media 
evaluated included soil, groundwater and surface water and sediment from the Arroyata River. As 
stated earlier, the Site is located just south of the main commercial district of Cidra in central eastern

constituents were identified as COPCs: Arsenic, Chromium, Vanadium, Cobalt Chloroform, PCE, 
Benzo (a) pyrene, 1,1,2-Trichloroethane, Bromodichloromethane, Dibromochloromethane, TCE and 
vinyl chloride. This document is available in the Administrative Record file (Appendix I). The 
contaminated media, concentrations detected, and concentrations utilized to estimate potential risks and hazards for the COPCs at the Site are presented in Table 1of Appendix VIII. 
 Exposure Assessment

controls to mitigate or remove hazardous substance releases. Cancer risks and noncancer hazard 
indices were calculated based on an estimate of  the reasonable maximum exposure (RME) expected

Toxicity Assessment 
 
Under current EPA guidelines, the likelihood of carcinogenic risks and noncancer hazards due to 
exposure to site chemicals are considered separate ly. Consistent with current EPA policy, it was 
assumed that the toxic effects of the Site-related chemicals would be additive. Thus, cancer and 
noncancer risks associated with exposures to individual COPCs were combined to indicate the 
potential risks and hazards associated with mixtures of potential carcinogens and noncarcinogens, respectively.  
 
Toxicity data for the human health risk assessment were provided by the Integrated Risk Information System (IRIS) database, the Provisi onal Peer Reviewed Toxicity Database, or other sources that 
were identified as appropriate references for toxi city values consistent with EPA’s directive on 
toxicity values. Table 2 and 3 of  Appendix VIII present a summar y of the noncancer and cancer 
toxicity data for the COPCs. Additional toxicity information for all COPCs is presented in the 
HHRA prepared for the Site.  
Risk Characterization 
 
Non-carcinogenic risks were assessed using the HI, based on a comparison of expected contaminant 
intakes and benchmark comparison levels of intake (reference doses, reference concentrations). 
Reference doses (RfDs) and reference concentrations  (RfCs) are estimates of daily exposure levels 
for humans (including sensitive individuals) which are thought to be safe over a lifetime of exposure. 
The estimated intake of chemicals identified in environmental media (e.g., the amount of a chemical 
ingested from contaminated drinking water) is compared to the RfD or the RfC to derive the Hazard 
Quotient (HQ) for the contaminant in the particular medium. The HI is obtained by adding the HQs for all compounds within a particular medium that impacts a particular receptor population.  
 
The HQ for oral and dermal exposures is calcul ated below. The HQ for inhalation exposures is 
calculated using a similar model that inco rporates the RfC, rather than the RfD. 
 HQ = Intake/RfD 
 
Where:  HQ = hazard quotient 
  Intake = estimated intake for a chemical (mg/kg-day) 
  RfD = reference dose (mg/kg-day)  
The intake and the RfD will represent the same e xposure period (i.e., chronic, subchronic, or acute). 
 
As previously stated, the HI is calculated by summing the HQs for all chemicals for likely exposure 
scenarios for a specific population. An HI greater than 1.0 indicates that the potential exists for non-carcinogenic health effects to occur as a result of Site related exposures, with the potential for health 
effects increasing as the HI increases. When the HI calculated for all chemicals for a specific 
population exceeds 1.0, separate HI values are th en calculated for those chemicals which are known 
to act on the same target organ. These discrete HI values are then compared to the acceptable limit of 
1.0 to evaluate the potential for non-cancer health effects on a specific target organ. The HI provides 18 
 a useful reference point for gauging the potentia l significance of multiple contaminant exposures 
within a single medium or across media. A summary  of the non-carcinogenic hazards associated with 
these chemicals for each exposure pathway is incl uded in Table 4-1 to 4-19 of Appendix VIII. 
 The total HIs for all current and future receptors, except current receptors at EA 2 and future 
trespassers at EA 1 and recreational users at th e Arroyata River under the RME scenario, are above 
EPA’s HI threshold of unity (1). The current a nd future workers at EAs 3 and 4 and the future 
construction workers at all exposure areas have n on-cancer HIs exceeding EPA’s threshold under the 
RME scenario for the kidney and respiratory system due to exposure to vanadium in soil. The current 
and future recreational users at the Arroyata River have non-cancer HIs exceeding EPA’s threshold 
under the RME scenario for the kidney and respiratory system due to exposure to vanadium in 
sediment and surface water. Cobalt and vanadium levels were consistent in soils and groundwater 
throughout the site and thus were not indicative of potential source areas. In addition, elevated cobalt 
and vanadium levels generally do not correlate well with the elevated Site ‐related contaminants in 
any of the soil samples or the groundwater samples.  Therefore, it is highly likely that cobalt and 
vanadium are naturally occurring analytes related to the volcanic geology in the area.  
 
Under the RME scenario, future residents have non-cancer HIs exceeding EPA’s threshold due to 
exposure to PCE, 1,1,2,2-TCA, TCE, arsenic, co balt and vanadium in groundwater and PCE, cobalt 
and vanadium in soil. Under the current CTE scenario, the total HIs are at or below EPA’s threshold for all exposure areas. Under the future CTE scenario s, the total HIs are still above EPA’s threshold. 
The potential non-cancer health hazards in groundw ater are due to exposure to PCE, arsenic and 
vanadium. The potential non-cancer hazards in soil are due to PCE, cobalt and vanadium. Risks 
associated with arsenic, cobalt, and vanadium are most likely overestimated. High levels of arsenic 
are likely due to remnants from the FLUTe liners (discussed below in the Uncertainties Section), while cobalt and vanadium are likely naturally occurring related to the volcanic geology in the area. 
 
For carcinogens, risks are generally expressed as the incremental probability of an individual 
developing cancer over a lifetime as a result of  exposure to a carcinogen, using the cancer slope 
factor (SF) for oral and dermal exposures and th e inhalation unit risk (IUR) for inhalation exposures. 
Excess lifetime cancer risk for oral and dermal exposures is calculated from the following equation, 
while the equation for inhalation exposures uses the IUR, rather than the SF: 
 
Risk = LADD x SF 
 Where:  Risk = a unitless probability (1 x 10
-6) of an individual developing cancer 
  LADD = lifetime average daily dose averaged over 70 years (mg/kg-day) 
  SF = cancer slope factor, expressed as [1/(mg/kg-day)]  
These risks are probabilities that are usually e xpressed in scientific notation (such as 1 × 10
-4). An 
excess lifetime cancer risk of 1 × 10-4 indicates that one additional incidence of cancer may occur in 
a population of 10,000 people who are exposed under the conditions identified in the assessment. 
Again, as stated in the NCP, the point of departure is 1 x 10-6 and the acceptable risk range for Site-
related exposure is 1 x 10-6 to 1 x 10-4. 
 
A summary of the estimated cancer risks is included in Table 5-1 to 5-12 of Appendix VIII. The

6 to 1×10-4 for the RME scenario. For the future land-use scenario, the estimated cancer risks for all 
receptors are either below or with in EPA’s target range for the RME scenario except future workers 
(2 x 10-4) and future residents (1 x 10-3) at all exposure areas. When a more typical exposure is 
considered under the CTE scenario, cancer risks for workers are within EPA’s target risk range, but 
cancer risks for residents are still above EPA’s target risk range due to exposure to arsenic in 19 
 groundwater.

Uncertainties in the Risk Assessment   As in any risk assessment, the estimates of potential health threats (cancer risks and non-cancer health hazards) have numerous associated uncer tainties. The primary areas of uncertainty and 
limitations are qualitatively. The main areas of uncertainty in this HHRA include environmental 
data, exposure parameter assumptions, toxico logical data, and risk characterization. 
 
Uncertainty is often associated with the estimation of chemical concentrations. Errors in the analytical data may stem from errors inherent in sampling and/or laboratory procedures. One of the 
most effective methods to minimize procedural or sy stematic error is to subject the data to a strict 
quality control (QC) review. The QC review procedure helps to eliminate many laboratory errors. 
However, even with all data rigorously validated, it mu st be realized that uncertainty is inherent in all 
laboratory procedures. 
 
Samples were collected from known and suspected areas of contamination (biased sampling) to 
delineate the nature and extent of contamination. Although this sampling methodology provided a 
reasonable estimation of the level of confidence at known or suspected contaminated areas within the 
Site, the possibility exists that the data sets formed by these samples do not accurately represent the level of overall contamination at the Site. The larg e number of soil, groundwater, surface water, and 
sediment samples taken from the Site, reduces uncertainty to an acceptable level in most cases.  
 
The groundwater data that were used in this assessment contribute to a degree of uncertainty to the 
overall assessment. Among the factors that should be considered is EPA’s ability to estimate risk in the future. The presumption that contaminant concentrations will remain the same over time may 
overestimate the potential risk because dispersion a nd other natural processes are not accounted for. 
 
It should be noted that three metals exceeding screen ing criteria were found to be risk drivers at all 
exposure areas – arsenic in groundwater, cobalt in soil, and vanadium in soil and groundwater. However, these metals are not considered Site-related contaminants as described in the RI Report. 
Arsenic was not detected in any of the source area groundwater samples from the Ramallo or IDC 
Properties . The most likely explanation for the levels  of arsenic in the Stage 1 groundwater 
investigation samples is that they are remnants from the blank FLUTe liners placed in the boreholes 
to prevent cross contamination between fracture zones. At the time the FLUTe liners were purchased, arsenic was used as a fungicide in the FLUTe liner urethane coating to resist mildew. 
Based on research by FLUTe, arsenic may leach into the water, although it is typically removed with 
standard well development procedures. EPA performed the standard purging of the MPWs prior to the first groundwater sampling round. However, arsenic was still detected in MPWs during the Stage 
1 groundwater investigation sampling. Except for one port, arsenic was not de tected during the Stage 20 
 2 groundwater investigation sampling. If the arsenic results from the Stage 1 groundwater 
investigation were excluded from the future resident risk calculations under the CTE scenario, it 
would yield a total cancer risk of 5×10-5, which is within EPA’s target cancer risk range of 1×10-6 to 
1×10-4, and a non-cancer HI (0.6) less than EPA’s threshold of unity based on exposure to arsenic in 
soil and groundwater. Hence, risks associated with  arsenic are most likely overestimated. More 
specific information concerning uncertainty in the health risks is presented in the HHRA Report. 
Cobalt and vanadium levels were consistent in soils and groundwater throughout the Site and thus 
were not indicative of potential source areas. In addition, elevated cobalt and vanadium levels 
generally do not correlate well with the elevated site ‐related contaminants in any of the soil samples 
or the groundwater samples. Therefore, it is highly likely that cobalt and vanadium are naturally 
occurring analytes related to the volcanic geology in the area. 
 
ECOLOGICAL RISK ASSESSMENT  
 
A Screening Level Ecological Risk Assessment (SLER A) was conducted to evaluate the potential for 
ecological risks from the presence of contaminants  in surface water and sediment in the Arroyata 
River. The SLERA focused on evaluating the potentia l for impacts to sensitive ecological receptors 
to Site-related constituents of concern through exposure to surface water and sediment in the 
Arroyata River which receives groundwater discharge from the plume. Surface water and sediment 
concentrations were compared to ecological screening values as an indicator of the potential for adverse effects to ecological receptors. A complete summary of all exposure scenarios can be found 
in the SLERA Report prepared for the Site. 
 
The data collected from the site were compared to conservatively derived ecological screening 
values as part of the SLERA. There were several compounds that exceeded an HQ of 1, specifically, 
aluminum, barium, lead and manganese in surface water and chromium, copper, cyanide, iron, 
manganese, mercury and nickel in sediments. Howeve r, none of the Site-related contaminants (i.e., 
TCE, PCE and their breakdown products) exceeded their respective screening values. The metals 
that were detected are not considered to be Site-related. Since no Site-related contaminants were 
above the conservative screening values, there is no unacceptable ecological risk from the Site associated with those contaminants.

REMEDIAL ACTION OBJECTIVES 
 
Remedial action objectives (RAOs) are specific goals to protect human health and the environment. 
These objectives are based on available information and standards, such as applicable or relevant and 
appropriate requirements (ARARs), to-be-consider ed (TBC) guidance and Site-specific risk-based 
levels. 
 
To protect human health and the environment, the following RAOs have been identified for this Site. 
 
RAOs for soil:  
 Prevent contaminated soil at the Site from serving as a source of groundwater 
contamination by isolating or remediating so il with contaminant concentrations exceeding 
groundwater protection remediation goals, discussed further below. 21 
  
 Prevent human exposure to contaminated soil at the Site having contaminant 
concentrations in excess of the remediation goals. 
 
RAOs for groundwater: 
 
 Prevent human exposure to contaminant concentr ations in groundwater above levels that 
are protective of drinking water. 
 
 Restore the groundwater to drinking water quality to the extent practicable. 
 
RAO for soil vapor: 
 
 Prevent or minimize impacts to public health resulting from the potential for soil vapor 
intrusion into buildings at and around IDC and Ramallo.

EPA has established expectations to use treatment to address any principal threats posed by a site. 
Principal threat wastes are those source materials considered to be highly toxic or mobile that 
generally cannot be reliably contained or would present a significant risk to human health or the environment should exposure occur. At both the IDC and Ramallo Properties, elevated 
concentrations of chlorinated VOCs were detected in the vadose zone at levels indicating the 
potential presence of DNAPL. PCE and, to a lesser extent, other contaminants, have migrated to the 
saprolite and the bedrock aquifers at the Ramallo Property. Although the aquifer within the Site is 
not currently in use, it is considered a potential drinking water source. Therefore, PCE contamination 
in the soil (potential for DNAPL) and the groundwater fits the definition of principal threat waste and 
requires remediation through treatment, where practicable.

  Institutional Controls  
 
Each action alternative would include institutional controls that would be implemented to help 
control and limit exposure to hazardous substances at  the Site. The objectives of institutional controls 
are to limit exposure to VOCs in soil and groundwater at the Site by preventing the excavation of 
contaminated soil and the installation of new dr inking water wells within contaminated areas. The 
types of institutional controls which would be employed for the soil and groundwater at the Site 
include local laws that limit installation of drinki ng water wells without a permit, deed restrictions 
that would limit the use of the Ramallo and IDC Properties to prevent any soil excavation or well 
installation, and informational devices such as advisories published in newspapers and periodic 
letters sent to local government authorities informing them of the need to prevent soil excavation and 
well installation at IDC, Ramallo and area within the contaminated plume. An Institutional Controls 
Implementation Action Plan (ICIAP) would be developed which would detail these institutional 
controls to insure that the remedy is protective.  The ICIAP would also include inspection of local 
and/or Commonwealth health department records to insure that no wells are installed that could 
impact the groundwater plume or result in exposure to contaminated groundwater.  
 
Institutional controls would also be required to  address vapor intrusion, as discussed below. 
 Vapor Mitigation  
 No current vapor exposures have been identified; however, the presence of elevated sub-slab vapors 
at several Site properties that are currently unoccupied serves as the basis for establishing 
institutional controls, monitoring, and potential response actions to address VI in the future. The IDC 
and Ramallo Properties are the only locations where response actions in soil are contemplated and 
where the potential for VI exposures may exist in the future, due to their close proximity to the 
relatively shallow soil source areas. These facili ties are currently vacant (with the exception of a 
second floor residence at the IDC Property, which is not currently affected by VI issues). 
Institutional controls, such as a deed restriction or covenant on these particular lots, would be needed 
to allow for notification of a change in occupancy, of use, or of new construction that might trigger a 
VI exposure to a new occupant. If occupied, the follo wing actions would need to be taken: sub-slab 
and indoor air sampling; subsequent periodic mo nitoring, vapor mitigation (such as sub-slab 
depressurization or sealing); and vapor mitigation inspection.  
 
For cost estimating purposes, it is assumed that  two sub-slab depressurization vapor mitigation 
systems would be installed and maintained at the IDC and Ramallo Properties.  
 
 Long-term Monitoring 
 A long-term Site groundwater monitoring program would be implemented until groundwater 
remediation goals are met. In addition, a long-term monitoring program of the Arroyata River 
surface water would be implemented to evaluate any impacts to water quality while the groundwater remedy is being implemented and to ensure that further migration of groundwater is not occurring. 
 
 Five-Year Reviews 
 
Alternatives resulting in contaminants remaining above levels that do not allow for unrestricted use 
and unlimited exposure require that the Site be review ed at least once every five years. If justified by 
the review, additional remedial actions may be considered to remove, treat, or contain the 
contamination. For remedial actions where unrestr icted use and unlimited e xposure is the remedial 
objective, it may require many years to reach that objective. It is EPA policy to conduct five-year 
reviews until remediation goals are achieved.  25 
  
 EPA Region 2 Clean and Green Policy 
 The environmental benefits of the preferred reme dy may be enhanced by giving consideration, 
during the design, to technologies and practices that  are sustainable in accordance with EPA Region 
2 Clean and Green Energy Policy. This will include consideration of green remediation technologies 
and practices. Some examples of practices that would be applicable are those that reduce emissions 
of air pollutants, minimize fresh water consumption,  incorporate native vegetation into revegetation 
plans, and consider beneficial reuse and/ or recycling of materials, among others.
