 Alternative R-S4 – In-situ  Treatment and Containment 
Under this alternative, in-situ  chemical treatment would be used to remediate the soil contaminated 
with high concentrations of VOCs and the remainde r of the soil at the Ramallo Property would be 
capped (Figure 22). A combined In-Situ  Chemical Reduction (ISCR)/bioremediation amendment 
would be long-lasting and would also promote abiotic degradation. The ISCR/bioremediation amendment treatment consists of introduction of amendments to provide a carbon source for further 
growth of dehalogenating microbes. Several types of amendments and amendment delivery 
processes could be utilized. The specific amen dment and delivery process would be confirmed 
during the design of the remedy. The amendments would be introduced with mechanical mixing in 
the surface soils, and the amendments would be distributed with environmental hydraulic fracturing to deeper soil intervals since injection alone in the low permeability clay would be ineffective. 
Environmental hydraulic fracturing would not be performed in the first 10 feet to avoid damaging 
nearby building foundations. Environmental hydraulic fracturing would introduce more moisture to enhance biological growth. However, introduction via discrete fractures cannot be expected to 
uniformly distribute amendments throughout the treatment zone, and there would likely be some 
gaps in treatment. As a result, not all of the contaminant mass would be removed from the clayey 
soil.  
 As in R-S2 and R-S3, a cap would be installed acros s the extent of the unpaved areas of the Ramallo 
Property to minimize infiltration of rainwater into residual contaminated soil. Regular monitoring 
and maintenance of the cap would be required until RAOs are achieved, as well as institutional 
controls to prevent disturbance of the cap and the building.  
 For cost-estimating purposes, it is assumed that the in-situ  treatment would implemented over 
approximately 10 years (with periodic in-situ  treatments over that span) to reach the remediation

 Alternative GW-2 – Groundwater Extraction, Treatment, and Long-term Monitoring 
 
Under this alternative, a groundwater extraction treatment system would be implemented in both the 
saprolite and the bedrock aquifers (Figure 23). This system would remove the chlorinated VOCs from the aquifer and also create a hydraulic barrier to further contaminant migration vertically into 
the bedrock and horizontally downgradient of the Ramallo Property. Extraction and treatment would 
continue until the aquifer has been restored. Long-term groundwater monitoring of contaminants in 
the saprolite and bedrock aquifers would be pe rformed to assess reme dial action performance. 
 
The groundwater extraction and treatment system wo uld include air stripping of the chlorinated 
VOCs. Air stripping involves the mass transfer of volatile contaminants from water to air by 
increasing the surface area of the groundwater exposed to air. Prior to release to the air, the 
chlorinated VOCs would be treated. Given the pres ence of low levels of vinyl chloride, the vapor 
phase treatment train for the air stripper off-gas  would first remove PCE and TCE with granular 
activated carbon, followed by treatment with potassium permanganate oxidation to remove cis-1,2-30 
 DCE and vinyl chloride. It is assumed that the wate r effluent from the air stri pper would be polished 
with activated carbon to meet PRWQS and then discharged to the Arroyata River. For costing 
purposes, it is assumed that the treatment system would operate for 30 years to reach the remediation 
goals; however, the system may need to operate in excess of 30 years to reach the remediation goals. Costs associated with alternative GW-2 are presented in Table 12.

  Alternative GW-4 – In-situ  Treatment and Long-term Monitoring 
 
In the saprolite zone, in-situ  treatment would be implemented under this alternative within a focused 
isocontour that would be determined after the pre-design investigation (Figure 25). The in-situ

chemical oxidant would be injected inside the 1,000 µg/L PCE isocontour in the saprolite zone. 
Similar to Alternative GW-3, a focused in-situ  treatment has the potential to be effective by 
removing higher concentrations at the center of the plume. The fringe areas of the plume would be 
allowed to naturally attenuate over time. The in-situ  treatment also has the potential to more rapidly 
clean up the contaminant plume but, unlike extraction and treatment (e.g., Alternatives GW-2 or GW-3), treating the center of the plume does  not actively prevent further migration. In-situ  treatment 
typically involves the addition of treatment amendments to the groundwater, followed by a period of 
monitoring, and then additional treatments based upon the monitoring results. A long-term monitoring program would be implemented and in-situ  treatment would continue, as needed, until 
the aquifer has been restored   
 
At the downgradient edge of the plume, a secondary treatment zone, such as a permeable reactive 
barrier or extraction and treatment system woul d be installed. The purpose of the additional 
downgradient treatment zone is to hydraulically control contaminant migration, allowing the in-situ  
treatment component discussed above sufficient contact time address the VOCs. It is currently 
anticipated that the secondary treatment zone would be installed after the in-situ  treatment system is 
in operation, so that it is designed to best support the operation of that remedial component. The 
exact location and scope of this remedial component would be determined after a treatability and/or pilot study; for cost estimating purposes, it was assumed that the secondary treatment zone would be 
placed at the edge of the 200 μg/L contour plume. 
 
Similar to Alternative GW-3, the fringe areas at the edge of the plume would be allowed to naturally

 COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS OF ALTERNATIVES 
 
In selecting a remedy, EPA considers the factors se t out in CERCLA Section 121, 42 U.S.C. Section 
9621, by conducting a detailed analysis of the viable remedial alternatives in accordance with the NCP, 40 CFR Section 300.430(e)(9)(iii) and the EPA Office of Solid Waste and Emergency 
Response (OSWER) Directive 9355.3-01. The detailed an alysis consists of an assessment of each 
alternative against each of nine evaluation criteria and a comparative analysis focusing upon the 
relative performance of each alternative against those criteria. 
The following "threshold" criteria are the most import ant and must be satisfied by any alternative in 
order to be eligible for selection: 
1. Overall protection of human health and the environment  addresses whether or not a remedy 
provides adequate protection and describes how risks posed through each exposure pathway 
(based on a reasonable maximum exposure scenar io) are eliminated, reduced, or controlled 
through treatment, engineering controls, or institutional controls. 
2. Compliance with ARARs  addresses whether or not a remedy would meet all of the applicable 
or relevant and appropriate requirements of ot her federal and state environmental statutes and 
regulations or provide grounds for invoking a wa iver. Other federal or state advisories, 
criteria, or guidance are TBCs. The NCP recogni zes that TBC may be used to determine what 
is protective of a site or how to carr y out certain actions or requirements. 
The following "primary balancing" criteria are used to make comparisons and to identify the major 
tradeoffs between alternatives: 
3. Long-term effectiveness and permanence  refers to the ability of a remedy to maintain reliable 
protection of human health and the environment over time, once cleanup levels have been 
met. It also addresses the magnitude and effectiveness of the measures that may be required 
to manage the risk posed by treatment residuals and/or untreated wastes. 
4. Reduction of toxicity, mobility, or volume through treatment  is the anticipated performance of 
the treatment technologies, with respect to these parameters, a remedy may employ. 
5. Short-term effectiveness  addresses the period of time needed to achieve protection and any 
adverse impacts on human health and the environment that may be posed during the 
construction and implementation period until cleanup levels are achieved. 
6. Implementability  is the technical and administrative feasibility of a remedy, including the 
availability of materials and services needed to implement a particular option. 
7. Cost includes estimated capital, O&M, and present worth costs. 
 
The following "modifying” criteria are used in the final evaluation of the remedial alternatives after 
the formal comment period, and may prompt modification of the preferred remedy that was presented in the Proposed Plan: 
8. State acceptance indicates whether, based on its review of the RI/FS report, Human Health 
and Ecological Risk Assessment, and Proposed Plan, the State concurs with, opposes, or has 
no comments on the selected remedy. 
 
9. Community acceptance  refers to the public's general respon se to the alternatives described in 
the RI/FS Reports, the Human Health and Ecological Risk Assessments, and the Proposed 
Plan.

SOIL ALTERNATIVES FOR IDC  PROPERTY  
 
Overall Protection of Human Health and the Environment 
 
Alternative IDC-S1 would not meet the RAOs and would not be protective of human health or the 
environment since no action would be taken. Contamination would remain in the soil at the IDC 
Property and no mechanisms would be implemented to prevent potential migration of contaminants to the underlying groundwater. 
 
Alternative IDC-S2 would meet the RAOs and would be protective of human health and the 
environment assuming the cap is properly maintained. Since the cap would minimize the infiltration 
of rainwater, it would reduce the potential for the contaminants to migrate to the underlying groundwater. An additional component included as part of this alternative is capping and vapor 
mitigation, as necessary, that would also mitigate potential exposure to chlorinated VOCs through 
direct contact or migration from contaminated soils, until the RAOs are achieved. 
 
Alternative IDC-S3 would provide treatment of the contaminants in the soil. While effective at reducing contaminant mass, some portion of the contaminants’ mass is expected to remain due to

PRINCIPAL THREAT WASTES 
 The NCP establishes an expectation that EPA will use treatment to address the principal threats 
posed by a Site whenever practicable (NCP S ection 300.430(a)(1)(iii)(A)). The “principal threat” 
concept is applied to the characterization of “source materials” at a Superfund site. A source material 
is material that includes or contains hazardous substances, pollutants, or contaminants that act as a 
reservoir for the migration of contamination to groundw ater, surface water, or air, or act as a source 
for direct exposure. Principal threat wastes are those source materials considered to be highly toxic or highly mobile that generally cannot be reliably contained, or would present significant risk to 
environment human health or the environment should exposure occur. The principal threat concept is 
applied to the characterization of source materials at  a Superfund site. A source material is material 
that includes or contains hazardous substances, pollutants, or contaminants that act as a reservoir for 
migration of contamination to groundwater, surface water or air, or acts as  a source for direct 
exposure. At the Site, high concentrations of chlorinated VOCs such as PCE, TCE and 1,1-DCE 
were detected in the soils at the IDC and Ramallo Properties which present a potential for migration 
to the groundwater, surface water or air. As such, principal threat waste is considered to be present at 40 
 the Site. PCE and, to a lesser extent, other contaminants have migrated to the groundwater within the 
Site which is a potential drinking water source in the area. Therefore, PCE contamination in the 
vadose zone and the below the water table in the sapr olite fits the definition of principal threat waste 
and would require remediation through treatment, wh ere practicable. The selected soil alternatives 
for the IDC and Ramallo Properties both rely on treatment to address the principal threats. 
 
SELECTED REMEDY 
 
SUMMARY OF THE RATIONALE FOR THE SELECTED REMEDY  
 
Based upon the requirements of CERCLA, the results of the Site investigations, the detailed analysis 
of the alternatives, and public comments, EPA has determined that the following combination of 
alternatives satisfies the requirements of CERCLA Section 121, 42 U.S.C. §9621, and provides the 
best balance of tradeoffs among the remedial alternatives with respect to the NCP’s nine evaluation criteria, 40 CFR §300.430(e)(9) described below. The principal components of the selected remedy 
are described below: 
  Alternative IDC-S3 (Soil Vapor Extraction and Contai nment), is the selected alternative for the IDC 
property. The remedy includes the following components: 
 
 Soil vapor extraction (SVE) to address the identified VOC hot spot in soil at the IDC 
Property; and 
 Capping in remaining unpaved areas of the IDC Property to prevent water infiltration and 
direct contact with contaminated soil, maintained until the hotspot is addressed through SVE. 
The existing concrete slab will also serve to cap contaminated soil underlying the building at 
the IDC Property. 
 
Alternative R-S3 (Enhanced Soil Vapor Extraction System with Thermal Treatment, Excavation/ 
Disposal/Backfill of Hot Spots, and Capping), is the selected alternative for the contaminated soil at 
the Ramallo Property. The remedy includes the following components:  
 
 SVE treatment enhanced with thermal treatment to address subsurface hot spot areas; 
 Excavation and off-site disposal of the most contaminated surface area hot spots located 
outside of the Ramallo Property building, with tetrachloroethylene concentrations that exceed 
the principal threat criterion of 166 milligrams per kilogram; and 
 Capping in remaining unpaved areas of the Ramallo Property to prevent water infiltration and 
direct contact with contaminated soil, maintained until the hot spot is addressed through SVE. The existing concrete slab will also serve to cap contaminated soil underlying the building at 
the Ramallo Property. 
 
Alternative GW-4 ( In-situ  Treatment and Long-Term Monitoring), is the selected remedial 
alternative for the groundwater plume located under and downgradient of the Ramallo Property. The 
remedy includes the following components:   
 In-situ  treatment within a focused area in the saprolite zone, at the center of the contaminant 
plume, using chemical or biological treatment methods to address the most highly 
contaminated portion of the groundwater;  
 establishment of a secondary treatment zone, such as a permeable reactive barrier or 
groundwater pump and treatment system, at the downgradient edge of the plume to manage 
plume migration; and 
 monitor natural attenuation of groundwater contaminants in the more dilute fringes of the 41 
 contaminant plume. 
 
DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF THE SELECTED REMEDY  
 
Soil at the IDC Property (Alternative IDC-S3) 
 Under this alternative, a SVE system will be used to address the identified hot spot at the IDC 
Property. Capping will be implemented in unpaved areas to prevent water infiltration and direct 
contact with contaminated soil, to be in place and maintained until the SVE system has addressed the soil contaminants. The existing concrete slab will also serve to cap contaminated soil underlying the 
building at the IDC Property. For cost estimating purposes, it is assumed that the area to be 
addressed under this alternative is approximately 100 ft
2 and 20 feet deep. Since the soil in this is 
low-permeability clay, air flow through the soil is expected to be low and treatment with SVE is 
likely to require closely spaced wells. The compressor for the system will be installed in the IDC Property building. It is anticipated that the system will run for up to 10 years to achieve the RAOs. 
Regular monitoring and maintenance of the caps and bui lding slab as well as institutional controls to 
prevent disturbance of the caps and the building slab  would be required until the RAOs are achieved.  
 
Soil at the Ramallo Property (Alternative R-S3) 
 
For this alternative, an SVE system (enhanced with thermal treatment) will target subsurface hot spot 
areas. Those hot spot areas are estimated to be present across a surface area of 1,000 ft
2 to a depth of 
80 feet. The SVE system will be installed inside the building at the Ramallo Property and heating 
electrode wells will be installed outside the buil ding on approximately 20-foot centers to the bottom 
of the hot spot areas. The electrical equipment, compressor for the system and the vapor and 
condensate treatment system will be located at Ramallo Property.  
 
Excavation and off-site disposal will target the most contaminated surface area with PCE 
concentrations located outside of the Ramallo Pr operty building that exceed the principal threat 
criterion of 166 mg/kg. After the disposal of the contaminated soil, clean soil will be used to backfill 
the excavated area. The extent of PCE excavation and the amount of soil required for backfilling will 
be refined during remedial design.   
A cap will then be installed in the unpaved areas of the Ramallo Property to cover all the outdoor 
areas to minimize infiltration of rainwater into any residual contaminated soil. The existing concrete 
slab will also serve to cap contaminated soil underlying the building at the Ramallo Property. 
Regular monitoring and maintenance of the cap and building slab as well as institutional controls to prevent disturbance of the cap and the building slab would be required until the RAOs are achieved.  
 Groundwater (Alternative GW-4) 
 In the saprolite zone, in-situ  treatment will be implemented within a focused area that will be refined 
after the pre-design investigation. The in-situ  treatment (i.e., chemical or biological treatment 
process) will target the most contaminated areas of the saprolite zone (i.e., center of the aquifer).  
 
For cost-estimating purposes, it is assumed that a ch emical oxidant will be injected inside the 1,000 
µg/L PCE isocontour in the saprolite zone. This focused in-situ  treatment is expected to be effective 
by removing higher concentrations at the center of the plume. The fringe areas of the plume will be 
allowed to attenuate over time, a process that will be aided by removing the most elevated levels 
through treatment. In-situ  treatment typically involves the addition of treatment amendments to the 
groundwater, followed by a period of monitoring, and then additional treatments based upon the 
monitoring results. A long-term monitoring program will be implemented and in-situ  treatment will 42 
 continue, as needed, until the aquifer has been restored to the extent practicable.  
 
At the downgradient edge of the plume, a secondary treatment zone, such as a permeable reactive 
barrier or extraction and treatment system will  be installed. The pur pose of the additional 
downgradient treatment zone is to hydraulically control contaminant migration, allowing the in-situ  
treatment component discussed above sufficient contact time address the VOCs. It is currently 
anticipated that the secondary treatment zone would be installed after the in-situ  treatment system is 
in operation, so that it is designed to best support the operation of that remedial component. The 
exact location and scope of this remedial component will be determined after a treatability and/or pilot study; for cost estimating purposes, it was assumed that the secondary treatment zone be placed 
at the edge of the 200 μg/L contour plume. If, during implementation of the remedy, it becomes 
apparent that the in-situ  treatment may be able to actively prevent further migration of the 
contaminant plume, EPA may determine that the secondary treatment zone is not necessary and 
would not implement this remedial component. At that time, EPA would record this significant change in the appropriate decision document in accordance with CERCLA.
 
 The fringe area beyond the secondary treatment zone (between the secondary treatment zone and the river) at the edge of the plume will be allowed to naturally attenuate while active remediation is 
performed in the core of the plume.  The use of in-situ  remediation and the placement of the 
secondary treatment zone upgradient of the MNA zone is expected to reduce the mass flux to a level 
that can be accommodated by MNA.  This MNA z one, approximately 200 feet by 300 feet in size, 
expected to naturally attenuate to acceptable levels within a reasonable timeframe.  Long-term monitoring of the saprolite and bedrock aquifers will be performed to ensure that natural degradation 
of the contaminants is occurring at an adequate rate. 
 
For cost-estimating purposes, it was assumed that the in-situ  treatment will be implemented over 
approximately 10 years (with periodic in-situ  treatments over that span) to reach the remediation 
goals in core of the plume and that the secondary treatment zone will be in place during that period. 
Relying on natural attenuation to address residual contaminants, a period of 30 years is estimated to 
reach the remediation goals in the entire aquifer. Groundwater modeling will be performed as needed 
during remedial design and after implementation of the remedial action will be used to assess the 
length of time it will take to achieve the RAOs, and monitoring and institutional controls would continue until RAOs are achieved.

 No current vapor exposures have been identified; however, the presence of elevated sub-slab

inspection (if applicable). 
 
 An Institutional Controls Implementation Action Plan (ICIAP) will be developed which will 
detail these institutional controls to insure that the remedy is protective.

 A Long-term monitoring program of the Arroyata River surface water will be implemented to

Five-Year Reviews 
 
 Alternatives resulting in contaminants remaini ng above levels that do not allow for unrestricted 
use and unlimited exposure require th at the Site be reviewed at le ast once every five years. If

conduct five-year reviews until cleanup levels are achieved.  
 
EPA Region 2 Clean and Green Policy 
 
 The environmental benefits of the selected re medy may be enhanced by giving consideration, 
during the design, to technologies and practices that are sustainable in accordance with EPA 
Region 2 Clean and Green Energy Policy. Th is will include consideration of green 
remediation technologies and practices. Some  examples of practices that would be 
appropriate are those that reduce emissions of air pollutants, minimize fresh water 
consumption, incorporate native vegetation into  revegetation plans, and consider beneficial 
reuse and/or recycling of materials, among others. 
 44 
 RATIONALE FOR THE SELECTED REMEDY  
 
For the IDC Property, Alternative IDC-S2 (containm ent) would be less effective than Alternative 
IDC-S3 (SVE and capping, the selected remedy) because the containment in Alternative IDC-S2 addresses direct contact threats but does not alle viate vapor intrusion threats or the potential for 
impact to groundwater. Alternative IDC-S3 also sa tisfies the CERCLA preference for treatment.  
 
For the Ramallo Property, Alternatives R-S2 (containment) would be less effective than Alternative 
R-S3 (enhanced SVE and capping, the selected remedy) because containment alone would not be expected to slow the flux of contamination from  soil into the underlying groundwater, and the source 
of groundwater and vapor intrusion would remain. A lternative R-S3 would be more effective than 
Alternative R-S4 ( in-situ  treatment and containment) because Alternative R-S4 is unlikely to be 
successful in uniformly distributing amendments throughout the treatment zone and achieving the 
RAOs in a reasonable time frame. Alternative R-S3 is best suited to treat the entire volume of contaminated material.  
 
With regard to the groundwater, Alternative GW-4 ( in-situ  treatment, the selected remedy) is 
expected to be more effective than Alternative GW-3 (focused groundwater extraction, treatment, 
and long-term monitoring) because Alternative GW-3 would only treat the hot spot. While 
Alternative GW-4 and Alternative GW-2 (Gro undwater Extraction, Treatment, and Long-term 
Monitoring) are both proven technologies that woul d successfully treat contaminated groundwater in 
the treatment zone, Alternative GW-2 would be significantly more expensive to construct and 
implement than Alternative GW-4. In addition, the time frame for achieving the RAOs for 
Alternative GW-4 is more certain than that of GW-2.

ESTIMATED OUTCOMES OF SELECTED REMEDY  
 
The principal outcomes of the selected remedy are: 1) to return the IDC Property and the Ramallo 45 
 Property to a productive use; 2) to prevent or  minimize exposure to contaminated soil and 
groundwater at concentrations exceeding the cleanup levels for ecological receptors through 
ingestion, inhalation and dermal contact; and 3) to remediate contaminated groundwater and restore 
it as a potential source of drinking water in a reasonable time period by reducing contaminant levels to the federal MCLs or more stringent Commonwealth standards. Productive use means the 
continued use of the properties per current zoning, i.e., commercial/residential use for the IDC 
property and commercial use of the Ramallo property. 
 
STATUTORY DETERMINATIONS 
 
CERCLA Section 121(b)(1) mandates that a remedial  action must be protective to human health and 
the environment, cost-effective, and utilize permanent solutions and alternative treatment 
technologies to the maximum extent practicable. Section 121(b)(1) also establishes a preference for 
remedial actions which employ treatment to permanently and significantly reduce the volume, toxicity, or mobility of the hazardous substances, pollutants, or contaminants at the Site. CERCLA 
121(d) further specifies that a remedial action must  attain a degree of cleanup that satisfies ARARs 
under federal and state laws, unless a waiver can be  justified pursuant to CERCLA 121(d)(4). For the 
reasons discussed below, EPA has determined that  the selected remedy meets the requirements of 
CERCLA Section 121. 
 
Protection of Human Health and the Environment 
 
The selected remedy will protect human health and the environment because it will restore 
groundwater quality at the Site to drinking-water st andards over the long-term, address direct contact 
threats, and mitigate the potential for exposure through a vapor intrusion pathway until the VOC hot 
spots are remediated. Institutional controls will also assist in protecting human health and the 
environment over both the short and long-term by he lping to control and limit exposure to hazardous 
substances. 
 
Compliance with ARARs 
 
There are no Federal or Commonwealth chemical -specific ARARs for soil. EPA developed risk-
based remediation goals and protection of groundwater values for soil at the IDC Property. The 
selected remedy for soil at the IDC Property will  comply with location-specific and action-specific 
ARARs (Table 6-1 and 6-2 of Appendix VIII).  
 
The remedy will address groundwater by achieving MCLs, which are drinking water ARARs.  This remedy is expected to comply with chemical, locat ion- and action- specific ARARs. Tables 6-1, 6-2 
and 6-3 of Appendix VIII summariz ed the location specif ic, action-specific and chemical ARARs. 
 
Cost Effectiveness 
 
A cost-effective remedy is one which has costs that are proportional to its overall effectiveness (NCP 
Section 300.430(f)(1)(ii)(D)). Over all, effectiveness is based on the evaluations of long-term 
effectiveness and permanence; reduction in toxi city, mobility, and volume through treatment; and 
short-term effectiveness. EPA evaluated the “overall e ffectiveness” of those alternatives that satisfied 
the threshold criteria (i.e., were both protectiv e of human health and the environment and ARAR-
compliant). Overall effectiveness was evaluated by assessing three of the five balancing criteria in 
combination (long-term effectiveness and permanence; reduction in toxicity, mobility, and volume 
though treatment; and short-term effectiveness). Ov erall effectiveness was then compared to those 
alternatives’ costs to determine cost-effectiveness. 
 46 
 Each of the alternatives underwent a detailed cost analysis. In that analysis, capital and O&M costs 
were estimated and used to develop present-worth costs. In the present-worth cost analysis, O&M 
costs were calculated for the estimated life of each alternative. The total estimated present-worth cost for implementing the selected remedy is $12.9 million. 
 
Based on the comparison of overall effectiveness to cost, the amended remedy meets the statutory 
requirement that Superfund remedies be cost-effec tive (NCP Section 300.430(f)(1)(ii)(D)) in that it 
is the least-costly alternative which will achieve groundwater standards within a reasonable time frame. The results of the analysis support the use for planning and estimating purposes of an 
estimate of a 30-year timeframe to remediate groundwater, although remediation timeframes could 
exceed or be shorter in duration than this estimate.

 Utilization of Permanent Solutions and Alternative Treatment (or Resource Recovery)

The selected remedy provides the best balance of tr adeoffs among the alternatives with respect to the 
balancing criteria set forth in the NCP Section 300.430(f)(1)(i)(B), because they each represent the 
maximum extent to which permanent solutions and treatment technologies can be utilized in a 
practicable manner at the Cidra Site. The selected remedy satisfies the criteria for long-term 
effectiveness and permanence by removing cont aminant mass with elevated levels of VOC 
concentrations. The combination of SVE, enhanced SVE and soil excavation at the soil source areas 
and in-situ  treatment for the groundwater will permanently reduce the mass of contaminants in soil 
and groundwater, thereby reducing the toxicity, mobility, and volume of contamination.  
 
Preference for Treatment as a Principal Element  
 
By using a combination of technologies, to the maximum extent practicable, the statutory preference 
for remedies that employ treatment as a principa l element is satisfied through the use of SVE and 
enhanced SVE to address contaminated soils, and in-situ  treatment to address contaminated 
groundwater.  
FIVE YEAR REVIEW REQUIREMENTS  
 
Because the remedy will not result in hazardous substances, pollutants, or contaminants remaining 
above levels that allow for unlimited use and unr estricted exposure in gr oundwater, EPA anticipates 
that a five-year review will not be required for the soil and groundwater remedy. However, because it 
may take more than five years to attain remedial action objectives and remediation goals for the soil and groundwater at the Site, policy reviews will  be conducted until the remediation goals are 
achieved to ensure that the groundwater remedy is, or will be, protective of human health and the 
environment.

On November 20, 2013, the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) released for public comment the Proposed Plan for the Cidra Groundwater Contamination Superfund Site. During 
the public comment period, EPA held a public meeting on December 4, 2013, to discuss and accept 
comments regarding the Proposed Plan. EPA received verbal comments during the public meeting as 
well as written comments during the public comment period, which lasted from November 20, 2013 
to December 20, 2013. This document summarizes comments from the public at the public meeting 
on December 4, 2013, and those submitted in wr iting during the public comment period. EPA’s 
responses are provided following each comment.  
 The comments are grouped generally in the following categories:  
 Background Information 
 Results of the Remedial Investigation 
 Remedial Alternatives 
 
Background Information 
 
Comment 1: Did the former industry located at IVAX use any solvents? Did EPA investigate the 
IVAX property?  
Response 1: EPA does not have any information regarding the use of solvents by the company 
located at the IVAX facility. The IVAX facility was one of the facilities investigated during the 
remedial investigation. A few VOCs were detected at IVAX but at levels below screening criteria 
and these VOCs were not  site-related VOCs. 
 
Comment 2:  Did the company located at the IVAX facility named Omark Antilles deposit their 
waste at the Cidra Landfill? 
 
Response 2: EPA does not have any information regarding the Cidra Landfill. However, at the 
public meeting when this question was asked, a re presentative from the Puerto Rico Environmental 
Quality Board (EQB) provided his name and telephone  number in order to be contacted and provide 
the information. 
 
Comment 3: Does EPA have any information regarding abandoned factories that could potentially 
affect the groundwater within the Centenejas area. 
 
Response : EPA does not have any information about that  particular area. However, EPA will accept 
any information regarding potential contamination in the area. 
 Comment 4 : Does EPA have any information regarding the contamination of the creek adjacent to 
the Cidra Landfill? 
 
Response 4 : The creek in question was not part of EPA’s study area. Because this area is not 
considered part of the Site, at the public meeting where this question was asked EPA referred this question to the EQB representative. The EQB re presentative took notes of the concern and will 51 
 investigate. 
 
Comment 5:  Concerns about the contamination created by industries in the area (specifically, in the 
Cidra Industrial Park) were raised regarding th eir effect on the public’s health and safety. 
 
Response 5:  EPA investigated many of the industries in the Cidra Industrial Park and determined 
that only the Ramallo Property requires remediati on. EPA acknowledges the concern and encourages 
any member from the community to provide information to EPA regarding any other release of 
contaminants to the environment.  
 
Results of the Remedial Investigations 
 
Comment 6:  Were any employees at the Ramallo or IDC facilities exposed to contaminants from the 
Site?  
Response 6: EPA does not have any information regarding past exposure to contaminants at these 
properties. While assessing any potential exposure, EPA used the data collected during the RI and 
assessed any present or future risk. If workers at either facility believe that they may have health 
problems as a result of working at these facilities,  they should contact the local health department. 
 
Comment 7:  A commenter asked for information about when the releases at the Site occurred. 
 Response 7:  EPA does not have information regarding the exact date of the releases. 
 
Comment 8:  How much of the contaminants were released into the environment? 
 
 
Response 8: Due in part to the volatilization of VOCs, it is not possible to estimate exactly how 
much contamination was released into the environment that has contaminated the Cidra Site 
groundwater. 
 
Remedial Alternatives 
 
Comment 9:  Does a remedy have the potential to affect surrounding structures? 
 
Response 9:  Although the soil vapor extraction enhancement might impact nearby structures, 
measures will be taken to prevent adverse impact to these areas.   
Comment 10 : A commenter ask if the former Shellfoam property could be redeveloped. 
 
Response 10:  The groundwater was the only media contaminated at the Shellfoam property due to 
the groundwater contamination migrating from Ramallo. The groundwater should not used until the remedy has cleaned up the groundwater contaminants.  
 
Comment 11: Will the selected remedy remove all the contaminants at the Site. 
 
Response 11: The remediation will reduce the concentrations of contaminants in the soil and 
groundwater to levels that are protective of human health and the environment; however, those levels 
are not zero. In addition, it will take as long as 30 years to reach protective levels in the groundwater. 
Under the Superfund program, five-year reviews of the remedy are conducted to while contamination remains on site, to determine how the remedy is affecting the contamination and determine if any 
additional actions need to be taken to address the contamination. 52 
  
Comment 12: How long will it take for the implementation of the remedial actions to begin? 
 
Response 12: The time to construct the three main components of the selected remedy are provided 
in the tables summarizing cost and time frame. The discussion also provides the approximate time 
required to achieve cleanup goals. Initiation of the construction also depends on the availability of 
funding, procuring contracts, and negotiations with  the potentially responsible parties. Based upon 
experience at other sites, it will take at least two years before parts of the remedy will begin to be 
implemented.  
Comment 13 : EPA should expedite the implementation of the remedies to avoid further migration of 
the contaminants. 
 
Response 13 : EPA will take actions to expedite the implementation of the remedies as soon as 
practicable. 
 
Comment 14 : Comite Despertar Cidreño sup ports the proposed alternatives. 
 
Response 14 : EPA acknowledges the support to the proposed alternatives.

SI
TE BACKGROUND 
Site Description  
The Sit e includes a plume of groundwater 
contaminated with chlorinated volatile organic 
compounds (VOCs) in an industrial area of 
Cidra (figure 1). Between March 1996 and 
August 2000, the Puerto Rico Department of 
Health (PRDOH) ordered the Puerto Rico 
Aqueduct and Sewer Authority (PRASA) to 
close four public supply wells in Cidra due to 3 | P a g e  tetrachloroethene (PCE) contamination. 1,1-
Dichloroethene (1,1-DCE) and trichloroethene 
(TCE) were also detected in these wells. 
PRASA closed the following public supply 
wells (figure 2): 
 Cidra Well #3 (Planta Alcantarillado), 
serving 112 people, closed in February 1999  
 Cidra Well #4 (Calle Padilla Final), serving 
177 people, closed in March 1996  
 Cidra Well #6 (Calle Baldorioty), serving 
207 people, closed in August 2000  
 Cidra Well #8 (Frente Cementerio), not in 
service, closed in October 1996. 
There are 15 active drinking water wells located 
within four miles of the Site, serving a total 
population of 8,838 people. The Site 
encompasses a small plateau and the densely 
populated Cidra commercial center, which 
consists of stores, private residences, municipal 
buildings and the town plaza. The Site also 
includes a drainage area to the south of the town 
center where some of the closed municipal wells 
are located, and the Cidra Industrial Park, which 
is i
n a valley to the southeast of the town center.   
The Site is located within an ecological zone of 
Puerto Rico characterized by moist-lowland 
forest. Another dominant land feature, a large 
municipal cemetery, is also present. 
Site History 
As described above, the Site includes four 
closed municipal wells, the Ramallo property 
located in the Puerto Rico Industrial 
Development Company (PRIDCO or 
FOMENTO in Spanish) Cidra Industrial Park, 
and a former dry cleaning facility, IDC, located 
in the commercial district of Cidra. 
According to information obtained by EPA, the 
lot owned by Ramallo was sold as a vacant lot 
to Sierra Instruments PR, Inc. in 1978. A 
company called Ramallo Escribano, Inc., (REI) 
purchased the property from Linear Packaging 
Inc. (Linear) and operated at that location from 
September 1986 to August 1990. REI 
manufactured flexographic labels at the Ramallo property. Ramallo purchased the property from 
REI in August 1990, at which time REI ceased

Topography and Drainage 
The municipality of Cidra is located in the 
central-eastern section of Puerto Rico in the 
northern foothills of the Cordillera Central 
Mountain Range. The Cidra commercial district 
is 
approximately 1,400 feet above mean sea 
level (msl). The topography generally slopes 
south from the commercial district to a narrow 
southwest-trending valley and an unnamed 
stream (referred to as the northern drainage 
area).  
In the vicinity of the Cidra Industrial Park, the 
topography slopes southwest toward the Rio 
Arroyata. The unnamed stream drains the area 
surrounding the Cidra municipal cemetery, and 
flows into the Rio Arroyata southwest of the 
Site (see figure 1). 
I
n general, most of the surface water drainage 
from the Site flows south and west across the 
Site toward the unnamed stream and the Rio 
Arroyata, a tributary of the La Plata River. 
Areas to the north and east of the Site drain into 
Cidra Lake located 0.5 mile east of the Site, 
which is part of the Bayamon River drainage 
basin. This lake is a man-made reservoir and is a 
popular fishing destination. A surface water 
intake for drinking water is located 
approximately 2.2 miles downstream of Cidra 
Lake. 4 | P a g e  Geology  
The geology in the vicinity of the Site is 
illustrated on the U.S. Geological Survey 
Comerio Quadrangle geologic outcrop map. The 
three strata encountered at the Site are the 
Quaternary-age terrace deposits composed of 
silt and clay, a saprolite layer (decomposed 
bedrock), and the underlying Cretaceous-age 
Pre-Robles volcanic rocks. The units are 
described below.  
Quaternary Upper Silty Clay – This 
unconsolidated overburden unit consists of 
reddish-brown silty clay grading to gray and 
brown silty clay. The depth to the bottom of the 
silty clay unit varies from 55 feet below the 
ground surface (bgs) at Saprolite Monitoring 
Well (SMW) SMW-1 to 105 feet bgs at SMW-
2; generally, the silty clay layer is thicker in the 
area near IDC than in the area near Ramallo.  
Saprol
ite Zone – The saprolite is the result of 
chemical weathering of the underlying volcanic 
rocks. The material is a hard, wet, brown to light 
brown, sandy to silty clay with abundant dark 
brown to brown, angular to very angular, mafic 
rock fragments with fine-grained texture. The 
saprolite crumbles easily under light pressure. 
Where present, the unit ranges in thickness from 
45 feet at Multiport Well (MPW) MPW-2 and 
MPW-3 to 60 feet at MPW-1. The contact 
between the saprolite and the underlying 
bedrock ranges from 109 to 156 feet bgs. At 
four locations, the depth ranges from 121 to 132 
feet bgs. 
Pre-Robles Volcanic Rock (Formation J ) - The 
core of the region is comprised of Cretaceous to 
Early Tertiary volcanic rocks of the Pre-Robles 
Formation (Formation J), which are the oldest 
rocks exposed in the Comerio geologic 
quadrangle. The rocks are estimated to be a 
maximum of approximately 8,900 feet thick and 
consist mostly of massive volcanic breccia, 
although lava flows and flow breccia occur 
throughout and are more common at the base 
and top of the unit. Massive to poorly stratified 
tuffs are interlayered with the volcanic breccia. Locally, volcanic conglomerates outcrop 
periodically. 
The supply wells and the multiport monitoring 
wells are completed in this unit, and well logs 
describe it as blue, brown, or black volcanic 
rock. A rock core collected from 123 to 328 feet 
bgs revealed volcano-clastic rocks consisting of 
well-defined dark bluish-gray to dark gray to 
dark reddish-brown clasts in a green fine-
grained matrix with inclusions of light greenish 
gray and white crystals. Some 1/8 inch to 1/4 
inch thick veins (possibly quartz) and 45 degree 
angle fractures (198 to 199 feet bgs) were 
observed in the core. Evidence of 
metamorphism was observed at 202 feet bgs.  
Key structural features in the vicinity of the Site 
include the Arroyata Fault, located 0.25 mile to 
the south of the commercial district and adjacent 
to 
the industrial park. The fault is weathered and 
has been hydrothermally altered across much of 
the area to the south of Cidra. Displacement 
along it is uncertain, but is generally strike-slip 
with a minor oblique component; it reverses to 
the east of Cidra.  
 Hydrogeology  
The aquifer of concern at the Site is the Pre-
Robles volcanic bedrock that underlies the area. 
The closed and active wells are finished in this 
aquifer at depths ranging from 110 to 705 feet 
bgs. It is the major aquifer beneath the Site. 
T
he Site is immediately underlain by the 
Quaternary upper silty clays, which overlie the 
fractured Cretaceous-age Pre-Robles volcanic 
bedrock. The saprolite zone lies between the 
silty clays and the bedrock. The hydrogeology 
of these units is described below.  
Hydrogeology of the Upper Silty Clay - Silts and 
c
lays have low permeabilities, which tend to 
hinder
 groundwater flow through the 
overburden to the water table. However, the 
fractures and lineations observed in the silty 
clays may provide secondary permeability that 
enhances groundwater flow to the underlying 
units. 5 | P a g e  Hydrogeology of the Saprolite Unit -  The 
saprolite zone below the silty clay was observed 
during the well installation to be a major water-
bearing unit; the saprolite stores water and 
provides recharge to the underlying bedrock 
aquifer. This unit is se mi-confined by the 
overlying silty clay soils, as evidenced by rising 
water level conditions in drilling rods upon 
reaching this zone. During well installation 
activities, very little water was encountered 
while drilling through the silty clay unit. Once 
the saprolite unit and groundwater were 
encountered, water levels rose approximately 20 
feet to 54 feet. Once in this unit, groundwater 
flows downward and laterally to the 
west/southwest and enters fractures at the top of 
the volcanic bedrock.  
Hydrogeology of the Pre-Robles Volcanic Rock 
- Groundwater flow in the bedrock is 
complicated by fractures and bedding planes 
and by the Site location relative to the two 
major river basins. The porosity of the bedrock 
is only two to three percent, but joints and 
fractures can enhance groundwater flow 
considerably. Bedding planes in the bedrock act 
as individual aquifers, separated by aquitards 
consisting of relatively low permeability 
bedrock, where less fracturing is present. Across 
the majority of the Site (west of the property 
owned by IVAX Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (IVAX)), 
groundwater encounters bedding planes in the 
bedrock aquifer and flows laterally along strike 
to the north and south and then down dip to the 
west. The resulting overall groundwater flow is 
to the west/southwest, toward the Rio Arroyata, 
located south and west of the Site.  
In the vicinity of the IVAX property, which is 
closer to the Arroyata Fault, bedding planes and 
fractures strike northwest/southeast, indicating a 
groundwater divide somewhere on the property. 
Based on the different strike and dip 
orientations in this area, groundwater in the 
bedrock flows to the southeast, toward an 
unnamed stream southeast of the IVAX 
property.  Ecological Reconnaissance

rea surrounding the Cidra municipal cemetery.

Meteorology  
The climate for the Cidra area is classified as 
tropical humid and is moderated by the nearly 
constant trade winds that originate in the 
northeast and its location in the foothills of the 
Cordillera Central Mountain Range. The 
average annual temperature for the Cidra area is 
72.7 degrees Fahrenheit (°F). Recent Cidra 
precipitation data indicates an average annual 
precipitation rate of 65 inches per year. 
Demographics and Land Use  
The Cidra Municipality is comprised of 36.5

EARLY SITE INVESTIGATIONS 
The PRDOH ordered PRASA to close the four 
public supply wells in the Municipality of Cidra 
due to the detection of PCE above federal 
maximum contaminant levels (MCLs). The source of contamination was  unknown at the 
time each well was closed. Several 
investigations were conducted to identify 
sources. A brief description of these 
investigations is provided below.  
EPA Expanded Site Inspection/Remedial 
Investigation, 2002 
In June 2002, several groundwater samples were 
collected by the EPA. Those samples were 
collected from the closed municipal supply 
wells and 20 other active and inactive wells 
located in Cidra. PCE was detected in the closed 
wells at concentrations ranging from 0.64 to 12 
micrograms per liter (µg/L). PCE was also 
detected in two industrial/potable supply wells 
(IVAX No. 1 and No. 2) and three industrial 
we
lls (Glaxo Smith Kline No. 1 and No. 2 and 
Mi
llipore - Cidra). Related chlorinated solvents, 
including 1,1-DCE, 1,1-dichloroethane, cis-1,2-
dichlor
oethene (cis-1,2-DCE), carbon 
tetra
chloride and TCE were also detected in 
groundwater samples.  
Federal MCLs for PCE (5 µg/L) and 1,1-DCE 
(7 µg/L) were exceeded in a number of wells 
tested, though not in any of the active drinking 
water wells. Other VOCs were also detected, in 
most cases at estimated concentrations below 
the sample quantitation limits. The investigation 
concluded that detections in the Glaxo Smith 
Kline wells and Millipore-Cidra industrial wells 
located east of Cidra Lake are likely not 
associated with the VOC source that impacted 
the closed public water supply wells.  
EPA Potential Source Area Investigation, 
2003 
In January and February 2003, the EPA 
investigated 12 industrial sites in the Cidra area 
to determine if they could be potential sources 
of contamination in the groundwater. Based on 
this investigation, EPA identified properties that 
re
quired further investigation as part of the RI.  7 | P a g e  EPA RI/FS - 2007 -2013 
An RI for the Site was conducted from July 
2007 through June 2012. The overall purpose of 
the 
RI was to identify potential source areas 
through soil, vapor intrusion and groundwater 
investigations, define the hydrogeologic 
framework, evaluate the nature and extent of 
groundwater, soil, soil vapor, surface water, and 
sediment contamination, and develop 
appropriate remedial alternatives for the 
identified contamination. The vapor intrusion 
investigation was conducted to determine the 
potential of vapor accumulation in the subslabs 
of structures and to determine if vapors have 
gained access to indoor air. Due to the lack of 
existing hydrogeological data and the lack of a 
defined source of contamination, a staged field 
investigation was planned to effectively use data 
collected during initial stages to focus and refine 
da
ta collection activities in the following stages. 
An FS was prepared to present and analyze 
cleanup alternatives suitable for the Site. The 
purpose of the FS was to identify, develop, 
screen, and evaluate a range of remedial 
alternatives for the contaminated media. The FS 
report provided the regulatory agencies with 
data sufficient to select a feasible and cost-
effective remedial alternative that protects 
human health and the environment from 
potential risks at the Site.

human health effects caused by hazardous-
substance exposure in the absence of any 
actions to control or mitigate these exposures 
under current and future land uses. In the

hazards. The four-step process is comprised of:

Toxicity Assessment, and Risk Characterization

assessment process).

Human Health Risk Assessment:  
A Superfund baseline human health risk assessment is an analysis of 
the potential adverse health effects caused by hazardous substance 
releases from a site in the absence of any actions to control or 
mitigate these under cur rent- and future -land uses.  A four -step 
process is utilized for assessing site -related human health risks for 
reasonable maximum exposure scenarios.  
 
Hazard Identification: In this step, the chemicals of potential concern 
(COPCs) at the site in various me dia (i.e., soil, groundwater, surface 
water, and air) are identified based on such factors as toxicity, 
frequency of occurrence, and fate and transport of the contaminants 
in the environment, concentrations of the contaminants in specific 
media, mobility, persistence, and bioaccumulation.  
 
Exposure Assessment:  In this step, the different exposure pathways 
through which people might be exposed to the contaminants in air, 
water, soil, etc. identified in the previous step are evaluated.  
Examples of exposure pathways include incidental ingestion of and 
dermal cont act with contaminated soil and ingestion of and dermal 
contact with contaminated groundwater.  Factors relating to the 
exposure assessment include, but are not limited to, the 
concentrations in specific media that people might be exposed to and 
the frequen cy and duration of that exposure .  Using these factors, a 
“reasonable maximum exposure” scenario, which portrays the 
highest level of human exposure that could reasonably be expected to 
occur, is calculated.  
 
Toxicity Assessment: In this step, the types of  adverse health effects 
associated with chemical exposures, and the relationship between 
magnitude of exposure and severity of adverse effects are 
determined.  Potential health effects are chemical -specific and may 
include the risk of developing cancer ove r a lifetime or other non -
cancer health hazards, such as changes in the normal functions of 
organs within the body ( e.g., changes in the effectiveness of the 
immune system).  Some chemicals are capable of causing both 
cancer and non -cancer health hazards.   
 
Risk Characterization:  This step summarizes and combines outputs 
of the exposure and toxicity assessments to provide a quantitative 
assessment of site risks for all COPCs.  Exposures are evaluated 
based on the potential risk of developing cancer and the  potential for 
non-cancer health hazards.  The likelihood of an individual 
developing cancer is expressed as a probability.  For example, a 10-4 
cancer risk means a “one -in-ten-thousand excess cancer risk”; or one 
additional cancer may be seen in a populat ion of 10,000 people as a 
result of exposure to site contaminants under the conditions identified 
in the Exposure Assessment.  Current Superfund regulations for 
exposures identify the range for determining whether remedial action 
is necessary as an individ ual excess lifetime cancer risk of 10-4 to 
10-6, corresponding to a one -in-ten-thousand to a one -in-a-million 
excess cancer risk.  For non -cancer health effects, a “hazard index” 
(HI) is calculated.  The key concept for a non -cancer HI is that a 
Athreshold @ (measured as an HI of less than or equal  to 1) exists 
below which non -cancer health hazards are not expected to occur.  
The goal of protection is 1 0-6 for cancer risk and an HI of 1 for a non -
cancer health hazard.  Chemicals that exceed a 10-4 cancer risk or an 
HI of 1 are typically those that will require remedial action at the site 
and are referred to as Chemicals of Concern or COCs in the final

Remedial action objectives (RAOs) are specific 
goals to protect human health and the 
environment. These objectives are based on 
available information and standards, such as 
applicable or relevant and appropriate 
requirements (ARARs), to-be-considered (TBC) 
guidance and site-specific risk-based levels.  
EPA has established expectations to use 
treatment to address any principal threats posed 
by a site. Principal threat wastes are those 
source materials considered to be highly toxic or 
mobile that generally cannot be reliably 
conta ined or would present a significant risk to 
human health or the environment should 
exposure occur. At both IDC and Ramallo, 
elevated concentrations of S ite-related VOCs 
were detected in the vadose zone at levels 
indicating the presence of DNAPL. PCE and, to 
a lesser extent, other contaminants have 
migrated to the saprolite and the bedrock 
aquifers at Ramallo. Therefore, PCE 
contamination in the vadose zone fits the 
definition of principal threat waste and would 
require remediation through treatment, where 
practicable. 
The media of concern at the Site are soil and 
groundwater. The source of soil contamination 
in the southern area of the Site is Ramallo and in 
the northern area of the Site is IDC. The 
groundwater contamination is located in the 
southern portion of the Site and based on the 
results of the RI, originates at Ramallo. Soil 
vapor samples show elevated soil vapor under 
the building slabs at both IDC and Ramallo, 
although there is currently no exposure because 
Ramallo is unoccupied and the lowest floor of 
IDC is unoccupied. Actions would be required if 
these spaces were to be occupied in the future. 
Site-related contaminants include PCE ,  TCE, 
cis-1,2 -DCE, 1,1-DCE, and vinyl chloride. 
These contaminants may pose risks to human 
health through inhalation, ingestion, and dermal 
contact.  RAOs are media-specific goals for protecting 
human health and the environment and serve as 
guidance for the development of remedial 
alternatives. To protect human health and the 
environment, RAOs have been identified. 
The RAOs for soil are: 
 Prevent contaminated soil at the Site 
from serving as a source of groundwater 
contamination by isolating or 
remediating soil with contaminant 
concentrations exce eding groundwater 
protection remediation goals, discussed 
further below. 
 
 Prevent human exposure to 
contaminated soil at the Site having 
contaminant concentrations in excess of 
the remediation goals. 
The RAO for soil vapor is: 
 Prevent or minimize impacts to public 
health resulting from the potential for 
soil vapor intrusion into buildings at and 
around IDC and Ramallo.   
The RAOs for groundwater are: 
 Prevent human exposure to contaminant 
concentrations in groundwater above 
levels that are protective of drinking 
water. 
 
 Restore the groundwater to drinking 
water quality to the extent practicable.

ALUATION OF REMEDIAL 
ALTERNATIVES 
During the detailed evaluation of remedial 
alternatives, each alternative is assessed against 
nine evaluation criteria, namely overall 
protection of human health and the envi-
ronment, compliance with applicable or relevant 
and appropriate requirements, long-term 
effectiveness and permanence, reduction of 
toxicity, mobility, or volume (T/M/V) through 
treatment, short-term effectiveness, 
implementability, cost, Commonwealth 
a
cceptance, and community acceptance. 
The
 evaluation criteria are described below. 
 Overall protection of human health and 
the environment  addresses whether or 
not a remedy provides adequate 
protection and describes how risks posed 
through each exposure pathway (based 
on a reasonable maximum exposure 
scenario) are eliminated, reduced, or 
controlled through treatment, 
engineering controls, or ICs. 
 
 Compliance with ARARs  addresses 
whether a remedy would meet all of the 
applicable or relevant and appropriate 
requirements of federal and state 
environmental statutes and requirements 
or provide grounds for invoking a 
waiver. 
 
 Long-term effectiveness and 
permanence  refers to the ability of a 
remedy to maintain reliable protection of 
human health and the environment over 
time, once cleanup goals have been met.  
It also addresses the magnitude and 
effectiveness of the measures that may 
be required to manage the risk posed by 
treatment residuals and/or untreated 
wastes. 
  Reduction of toxicity, mobility, or 
volume through treatment  is the 
anticipated performance of the treatment 
technologies, with respect to these 
parameters, a remedy may employ. 
 
 Short -term effectiveness  addresses the 
period of time needed to achieve 
protection and any adverse impacts on 
human health and the environment that 
may be posed during the construction 
and implementation period until cleanup 
goals are achieved. 
 
 Implementability  is the technical and 
administrative feasibility of a remedy, 
including the availability of materials 
and services needed to implement a 
particular option. 
 
 Cost includes estimated capital and 
O&M costs and net present-worth costs.   
 
 Commonwealth acceptance  indicates if, 
based on its review of the RI/FS reports 
and Proposed Plan, the Commonwealth 
concurs with the preferred remedy at the 
present time. 
 
 Community acceptance  would be 
assessed in the ROD and refers to the 
public's general response to the 
alternatives described in the Proposed 
Plan and the RI/FS reports.

based upon the evaluation criteria noted above 
is presented below.

GLOSSARY 
ARARs: Applicable or Relevant and 
Appropriate Requirements. These are Federal or 
more stringent State environmental rules and 28 | P a g e  regulations that may pertain to the site or a 
particular alternative.  
Carcinogenic Risk: Cancer risks are expressed 
as a number reflecting the increased chance that 
a person will develop cancer if exposed to 
chemicals or substances. For example, EPA’s 
acceptable risk range for Superfund hazardous 
waste sites is 1 x 10-4 to 1 x 10-6, meaning there 
is 1 additional chance in 10,000 (1 x 10-4) to 1 
additional chance in 1 million (1 x 10-6) that a 
person will develop cancer if exposed to a site 
contaminant that is not remediated.  
CERCLA: Comprehensive Environmental 
Response, Compensation and Liability Act. A 
Federal law, commonly referred to as the 
“Superfund” Program, passed in 1980 that 
provides for response actions at sites found to be 
contaminated with hazardous substances, 
pollutants or contaminants that endanger public 
health and safety or the environment. 
CERCLIS: Comprehensive Environmental 
Response Compensation and Liability 
Information System 
COPC: Chemical of Potential Concern.  
SLERA: Screening Level Ecological Risk 
Assessment. An evaluation of the potential risk 
posed to the environment if remedial activities 
are not performed at the site.  
FS: Feasibility Study. Analysis of the 
practicability of multiple remedial action 
options for the site. 
Groundwater: Subsurface water that occurs in 
soils and geologic formations that are fully 
saturated.  
HHRA: Human Health Risk Assessment. An 
evaluation of the risk posed to human health 
should remedial activities not be implemented.  
HI: Hazard Index. A number indicative of non-
carcinogenic health effects that is the ratio of the 
existing level of exposure to an acceptable level 
of exposure. A value equal to or less than one indicates that the human population is not likely 
to experience adverse effects.  
HQ: Hazard Quotient. HQs are used to evaluate 
non-carcinogenic health effects and ecological 
risks. A value equal to or less than one indicates 
that the human or ecological population is not 
likely to experience adverse effects.  
ICs: Institutional Controls. Administrative 
methods to prevent human exposure to 
contaminants, such as by restricting the use of 
groundwater for drinking water purposes.  
MCLs: Maximum Contaminant Levels. 
Standards that are set by the EPA for drinking 
water quality. An MCL is the legal threshold 
limit on the amount of a substance that is 
allowed in public water systems under the Safe 
Drinking Water Act. The limit is usually 
expressed as a concentration in milligrams or 
micrograms per liter of water. 
Nine Evaluation Criteria: See the "Evaluation of

LA EPA ANUNCIA EL PLAN 
PROPUESTO DE LIMPIEZA  
Este Plan Propuesto describe las alternativas 
remediales evaluadas para el Lugar de Superfondo de Contaminación de Agua Subterránea (el Lugar) de Cidra, en Cidra, Puerto Rico, e identifica el remedio preferido para este Lugar con la razón para esta preferencia.  Este documento fue desarrollado por la Agencia Federal de Protección Ambiental (EPA, por sus siglas en inglés), agencia principal para las actividades del Lugar, en consulta con la Junta de Calidad Ambiental (JCA), la agencia de apoyo.  La Agencia Federal de Protección Ambiental (EPA) emite este Plan Propuesto como parte de sus requisitos bajo la sección 117 (a), de Respuesta Ambiental Comprensiva, Ley de Compensación y Responsabilidad (CERCLA, por sus siglas en inglés, comúnmente conocida como el programa de Superfondo) y las Secciónes 300.430(f) y 300.435(c) del Plan de C ontingencia Nacional 
de Contaminación de Petróleo y Sustancias Peligrosas (NCP, por sus siglas en inglés).   
La naturaleza y el alcance de la contaminación 
en el Lugar y las alternativas remediales resumidas en este documento están descritas en detalle en los informes de Investigación Remedial (RI, por sus siglas en inglés) y el Estudio de Viabilidad (FS, por sus siglas en inglés).    
El remedio preferido por la EPA para el Lugar 
consiste de las siguientes alternativas del FS para atender la contam inación del suelo y del 
agua subterránea en el Lugar:  
 Alternativa IDC-S3 – Extracción y 
Encapsulado de Vapor en el Suelo  en la propiedad operada anteriormente por 
International Dry Cleaners (IDC).  
 Alternativa R-S3 – Extracción del Vapor del 
Suelo con Tratamiento Termal; Excavación, 
Disposición y Relleno; y Encapsulado en la propiedad operada anteriormente por Ramallo Bros. (Ramallo).

ALCANCE Y ROL DE LA ACCIÓN 
La EPA está atendiendo la limpieza de este 
Lugar implementando una acción remedial abarcadora para atender la contaminación del suelo, vapor del suelo y de aguas subterráneas en el Lugar.    3 | Page  HISTORIAL DEL LUGAR  
Descripción del Lugar 
El lugar incluye una plumacho de agua 
subterránea contaminada con compuestos orgánicos clorinados vo látiles (VOCs, por sus 
siglas en inglés) en un área industrial de Cidra 
(figura 1).  Entre marz o de 1996 y agosto de 
2000 el Departamento de Salud de Puerto Rico (PRDOH, por sus siglas en inglés) le ordenó a la Autoridad de Acueductos y Alcantarillados de Puerto Rico (PRASA, por sus siglas en inglés) a cerrar cuatro pozos de agua de suministro público en Cidra debido a contaminación con tetracloroetileno (PCE,por su s siglas en inglés). 
1,1-Dicloroetileno (1,1-DCE) y tricloroetileno (TCE) también fueron detectados en estos pozos.  PRASA cerró los siguientes pozos de suministro público (figura 2):  
 Pozo Cidra #3 (Planta Alcantarillado), 
sirviendo a 112 personas, cerrado en febrero 
de 1999  
 Pozo Cidra #4 (Calle Padilla Final), 
sirviendo a 177 personas, cerrado en marzo 1996  
 Pozo Cidra #6 (Calle Baldorioty), sirviendo 
a 207 personas, cerrado en agosto de 2000  
 Pozo Cidra #8 (Frente Cementerio), fuera de servicio, cerrado en  octubre de 1996 
Hay 15 pozos activos de agua potable 
localizados dentro de un radio de cuatro millas del Lugar, sirviendo a una población total de 8,838 personas.  El Lugar consiste de una pequeña meseta y el densamente poblado centro comercial de Cidra, incluyendo tiendas, residencias privadas, edificios municipales y la plaza de recreo.  Este Lugar también incluye un 
área de drenaje al su r del centro del pueblo 
donde están localizados algunos de los pozos municipales cerrados y el  Parque Industrial de 
Cidra, el cual está en  un valle al sureste del 
centro del pueblo.  
El Lugar está localiza do dentro de una zona 
ecológica de Puerto Rico caracterizada por 
bosques húmedos de tierras bajas.  Otro distintivo dominante en el área es el cementerio municipal, que es muy grande.     
Historial del Lugar 
Como se describe ante riormente, el Lugar 
incluye cuatro pozos m unicipales cerrados, la 
propiedad de Ramallo localizada en el Parque Industrial de Cidra de la  Compañía de Fomento 
Industrial de Puerto Rico (PRIDCO, por sus siglas en inglés o FOMENTO en Español), y una instalación que er a anteriormente una 
lavandería llamada International Dry Cleaner (IDC) localizada en el distrito comercial de Cidra.   
De acuerdo con la información obtenida de 
PRIDCO por la EPA, el lote perteneciente a la propiedad de Ramallo fue vendido como un lote vacante a Sierra Instruments, PR., en el 1978.  En su respuesta a la Solicitud de Información de la EPA, Ramallo indicó que en agosto de 1986, una compañía llamada Ramallo Escribano, inc. (REI) compró la propiedad a Linear Packaging, Inc. (Linear) y operó en esa localidad desde septiembre de 1986 hasta agosto de 1990.  REI fabricaba etiquetas flexog ráficas en la propiedad 
Ramallo. Ramallo compró la propiedad de REI en agosto de 1990, momento en el cual REI cesó operaciones y las acciones de su compañía fueron vendidas a Ramallo.  La propiedad de Ramallo ha estado desocupada desde el 2007. 
La propiedad IDC está localizada en la Avenida 
Muñoz Rivera en Cidra, a menos de 0.1 millas al noreste del Pozo Cidra 4, uno de los pozos municipales cerrados.  International Dry Cleaning había estado operando en la instalación desde aproximadamente el 1994, 
aunque durante sus operaciones el IDC no tenía 
permiso de RCRA en expediente con la EPA.  La planta baja del edificio de la propiedad de IDC está actualmente vacante.  No obstante, una unidad residencial en el segundo piso está 
actualmente ocupada. 
Topografía y Drenaje  
El municipio de Cidra está localizado en la 
sección este-central de Puerto Rico al pie del 4 | Page  área norte de la Sierra de la Cordillera Central.  
El distrito comercial de Cidra está aproximadamente a 1,400 pies de altura sobre el nivel del mar (msl, por sus si glas en inglés).   La 
topografía generalmente se inclina al sur desde el distrito comercial ha sta un valle angosto con 
tendencia al sur y un arroyo sin nombre (al que se refiere como el área de drenaje del norte).    
En las inmediaciones del Parque Industrial de 
Cidra, la topografía se in clina al suroeste hacia 
el Río Arroyata.  El arroyo sin nombre drena el área alrededor del ceme nterio municipal de 
Cidra, y fluye hacia el Rí o Arroyata al suroeste 
del Lugar.  (Ver figura 1).  
En general, la mayoría del drenaje del agua de 
superficie del Lugar fluye  al sur y al oeste a 
través del Lugar hasta el arroyo sin nombre y el 
Río Arroyata, un tributario del Río La Plata. Áreas al norte y al este del Lugar drenan en el Lago de Cidra localizado a 0.5 millas al este del Lugar, el cual es parte de la cuenca de drenaje del Río Bayamón.  Este  lago es una reserva 
hecha por el hombre y es un destino popular para pescar.  Una toma de agua de superficie utilizada para agua potable se encuentra localizada aproximadamente a 2.2 millas río 
abajo del Lago de Cidra.   
Geología  
La geología en las inmediaciones del Lugar está 
ilustrada en el mapa geológico de la  medición  del Cuadrángulo de Comerío del Servicio Geológico de EEUU.  Los tres estratos encontrados en el Lugar son depósitos de material esteril (overbur den) del cuaternario; 
compuestos de cieno y arcilla, una capa de 
saprolíta (roca descom puesta), y las rocas 
volcánicas subyacentes del Cretácico de la 
Formación Pre-Robles (roca de fondo).  Las unidades se describen a continuación.     
Arcilla Cuaternaria Superior Cienosa  –  Esta 
unidad no consolidada de material estéril consiste de arcilla ci enosa marrón rojizo con 
una gradación a una arcilla cienosa gris y marrón.  La profundidad hasta el fondo de la unidad de arcilla cienosa varía desde los 55 pies bajo la superficie del su elo (bgs, por sus siglas 
en inglés) en el Pozo de Monitoreo en la zona saprolítica (SMW, por sus siglas en inglés) SMW-1 a 105 pies bgs en SMW-2; generalmente, la capa de arcilla cienosa es más densa en el área cercana a IDC que en el área cercana a Ramallo.   
Zona Saprolítica –  La saprolíta es el resultado 
del desgaste de las rocas volcánicas 
subyacentes.  El material es duro, mojado, de color marrón a marrón claro, arcilla cienosa a arenosa con abundante marrón oscuro o marrón, angular a muy angular, fragmentos de roca máfica con textura de grano fino.  La roca 
saprolítica se desmorona bajo presión leve.  Cuando está presente, la unidad varía en grosor desde 45 pies en el Pozo Multipuerto (MPW, por sus siglas en inglés) MPW-2 y MPW-3 hasta 60 pies en MPW-1.  El contacto entre la roca saprolítica y la roca de fondo subyacente varía de 109 a 156 pies bgs.  En cuatro localizaciones, la profundidad varía de 121 a 132 pies bgs.   
Roca Volcánica Pre-Robles (Formación J) -  El 
núcleo de esta región se compone de rocas 
volcánicas del Cretacio al Terciario Temprano 
de la Formación Pre-Robles (Formación J), las 
cuales son las rocas más antiguas expuestas en el cuadrángulo geológico de Comerío.  Se ha estimado un grosor máximo de aproximadamente 8,900 pies de ancho y consisten mayormente de rocas volcánicas conglutinadas masivas, aunque el flujo de lava y el flujo de piedras congl utinadas ocurre a lo 
largo de y es más común en la base y en el tope de la unidad.  Tobas volcánicas de estratificación masiva a pobre están intercaladas 
con las brechas volcánicas.  Localmente, los conglomerados volcánicos afloran periódicamente.   
Los pozos de suministro  y los pozos multipuerto 
de monitoria fueron completados en esta unidad, 
y los registros de los pozos los describen como de rocas azules, marrones o negras volcánicas.  Un núcleo de roca recolectado de 123 a 328 pies bgs reveló que las ro cas volcanoclásticas 5 | Page  consistentes de clastos bien definidos de color 
gris oscuro azulado a gris oscuro a marrón rojizo oscuro en una matriz verde de grano fino con inclusiones en cristales de un gris verdoso claro y blanco.  Algunas venas de 1/8 pulgadas a 1/4 pulgadas de densidad (posiblemente cuarzo) y fracturas de ángulo de 45 grados (198 a 199 
pies bgs) se observaron en  el núcleo.  Evidencia 
de metamorfismo se observó a 202 pies bgs.    
Rasgos estructurales claves en las 
inmediaciones del Lugar incluyen la Falla Arroyata, localizada a 0.25 millas al sur del distrito comercial y adyacente al parque industrial.  La falla está erosionada y ha sido alterada hidrotermalmente  a lo largo de gran 
parte del área al sur de Cidra.  El desplazamiento a lo largo de ella es incierto, pero es generalmente una falla de desgarre con un componente menor oblicuo; siendo inversa al este de Cidra.   
 
Hidrogeología  
El acuífero de interés en el Lugar se encuentra en la roca volcánica de la Formación Pre-Robles, que subyace al área.  Los pozos cerrados y activos están terminados en este acuífero a profundidades que van desde 110 a 705 pies de profundidad.  Este es el mayor acuífero por debajo del Lugar.     
Al Lugar subyace la arcilla cienosa superior del 
Cuaternario, la cual c ubre la roca volcánica 
fracturada de la Formación Pre-Robles del Cretácico.  La zona sa prolítica se encuentra 
entre las arcillas cienosas  y la roca volcánica de 
fondo.  La hidrogeología de  estas unidades está 
descrita a continuación.    
Hidrogeología de la Arcilla Cienosa Superior – 
Cienos y arcillas tienen baja permeabilidad, lo 
que tiende a obstruir el flujo del agua 
subterránea a través de la cubierta hasta el nivel freático.  Sin embargo, las fracturas y las juntas observadas en las arcillas cienosas pueden proveer permeabilidad secundaria que mejora el flujo del agua subterránea a las unidades subyacentes.    Hidrogeología de la Unidad Saprolítica -–  La 
zona saprolítica que se encuentra debajo de la arcilla cienosa fue identificada durante la instalación de los poz os como una unidad 
acuífera mayor; la saprolítica almacena agua y provee recarga al acuífero de la roca de fondo subyacente.  Esta unidad está semi-confinada por los suelos de arcilla cienosa suprayacentes, como se evidencia por las condiciones crecientes de los niveles de agua en las varillas de perforación al llegar a esta zona.   Durante las actividades de instal ación de los pozos, bien 
poca agua se encontró mientras se perforaba la unidad de arcilla  cienosa.  Una vez la zona 
saprolítica y el agua subterránea fueron encontradas, los nivele s del agua ascendieron 
aproximadamente unos 20 a 54 pies.  Una vez en esta unidad, el agua subterránea fluye pendiente abajo y lateralmente al oeste/suroeste y entra en las fracturas en  el tope de la roca 
volcánica de fondo.   
Hidrogeología de la Roca  Volcánica Pre-Robles 
– El flujo de agua subterránea en la roca de 
fondo se complica por fracturas y planos de 
estratificación y por la localización del Lugar relativo a las dos mayore s cuencas de río.  La 
porosidad de la roca de fondo es de sólo 2 o 3 porciento, pero las diaclasas y las fracturas pueden mejorar considerablemente el flujo del agua subterránea.  Los planos de estratificación 
en la roca de fondo actúan como acuíferos individuales, separados por acuitardos causados 
por la roca de fondo de permeabilidad relativamente baja, donde hay menos fracturas.  A lo largo de la mayoría del Lugar (al oeste de la propiedad perteneciente a IVAX Pharmaceuticals, Inc.  (IVAX)), el agua 
subterránea se encuentra con planos de estratificación en el acuíf ero de la roca de fondo 
y fluye lateralmente a lo largo de la dirección del estrato al norte y al sur y luego con un 
buzamiento abajo al oeste.   El agua subterránea en general fluye hacia el oeste/suroeste, hacia el Río Arroyata, localizado al sur y oeste del Lugar.   
En las inmediaciones de la propiedad IVAX, la 
cual está más cercana a la Falla Arroyata, los 6 | Page  planos de estratificaci ón y las fracturas a lo 
largo del estrato al noro este/sureste, indicando 
que existe una división del flujo de agua 
subterránea en algún lugar de la propiedad.   Basado en las diferentes orientaciones del estrato e inclinación  en esta área, el agua subterránea en la roca de  fondo fluye al sureste, 
hacia un arroyo sin nombre  al sureste de la 
propiedad IVAX.    
Reconocimiento Ecológico  
La topografía y el drenaje del agua de superficie en el Lugar dan al sur/suroeste hacia el Río Arroyata y el arroyo si n nombre que drena el 
área alrededor del ceme nterio municipal de 
Cidra.    
La porción del Río Arroyata incluida en el 
reconocimiento ecológico para este Lugar puede 
ser caracterizado como una corriente de gradiente baja/moderada, compuesto de varias secuencias de pozas/corridas/charcos no más de tres a cinco pies de ancho, con una profundidad 
que va desde algunas pulgadas a más de un pie en pozos.  Los taludes a las orillas del rio 
tienden a ser relativamente empinadas.   Las pilas de detrito y las orillas erosionadas sugieren un flujo de moderado a alto durante eventos de precipitación.

La PRDOH ordenó a la PRASA a cerrar cuatro

Inspección Expandida del Lugar 
/Investigación Remedial por la EPA, 2002  
En junio de 2002, la EPA tomó varias muestras 
de agua subterránea.  Esas muestras fueron tomadas de los pozos de suministro municipal y otros 20 pozos activos e in activos en Cidra.  Se 
detectó PCE en los pozos cerrados en concentraciones que iban desde 0.64 a 12 microgramos por litro (µg/L). También se detectó PCE en dos pozos de suministro industrial/potable (IVAX No. 1 y No. 2) y tres pozos industriales (Glaxo Smith Kline No. 1 y No. 2 y Millipore - Cidra) .  Solventes clorados 
relacionados, incluyendo 1,1-DCE, 1,1-dicloroetano, cis-1,2-d icloroetileno (cis-1,2-
DCE), tetracloruro de carbón y TCE también fueron detectados en las muestras de agua subterránea.    
Los MCLs ferales para PCE (5 µg/L) y 1,1-DCE 
(7 µg/L) fueron excedidos en ciertos pozos examinados, aunque no en ninguno de los pozos activos de agua potable. los pozos de Glaxo Smith Kline y en los pozos industriales de Millipor e-Cidra, localizado al
